The Earl of Northampton went into Scotland with a great company of armed men,
and Archers, where he rode through the marches, and enforced ye Castle of
Loghmaban, and other fortresses to yield, and took the Scotts that were laid
in ambushes. He also held a treaty of peace with the Scotts, who gladly would
have redeemed their King, and made a perpetual peace with the Englishmen* but
yet so as the King of Scotts should not hold his land of the King of England.

William Weld: John Little, the 28. of September. Sherifes. Mayor.


Adam Francis Mercer, the 28. of October.

Innocent the 6. for the desire of peace, sent the Cardinal of Bononi to
Caleis, to hear the treaty of the final peace betwixt Treaty of peace.
the Kingdoms of England and France, to whom repaired the Counselors of
both Realms, with full authority to treat and constitute the conditions of
the same peace, and at length they agreed upon this point, that the King of
England should resign all his right that he had to the Realm of France, and
remitte it to the French King, and should have therefore the Duchy of
Aquitayne, and the Counties of Artoys and of Guisnes, for him and his
successors Kings of England, without that he should hold the Counties.
same of the French King in any manner of wise. To these conditions the King of
England gave his consent, and for the assurance of the covenants,
Embassadoures are sent to the Sea of Rome from either Realm. On the King of
Englands Anno reg. 28.
behalf went the Bishop of Norwich, the Duke of Lancaster, the Earl of
Arundell, and other knights, who going to Auinion, there came to them the
Archbishop of Rohan, the Duke of Burgoigne, Geffrey Charney, and other of the
French Kings Counsel: all these were received in great honor: many Cardinals
and Bishops met the Duke of Lancaster, who brought him for the space of two
miles unto Auinion, and to the Popes Palace: at length in the Consistory of
the Pope, he with the Cardinals and Embassadoures being present, the causes
of their message was declared, and the Embassadoures of England requested to
have the covenants confirmed, which had bin concluded at Caleis: to whom the
Frenchmen answered, that gladly they would have peace, but touching Aquitaine,
and the foresaid Countries, as they said, the French King could not, nor they
might give their assents that the same should be alienated from the entire
body of the Kingdom, to the which, as well the King as they had taken an oath
to maynteyne, but yet they could be contented that the profitable dominion of
the said Duchy and Countries should be delivered, and come to the King of
England, as his auncesters had Aquitayne, but so yet as the regalitie of the
Crown of France should ever be reserved. The Englishmen requested that these
said dominions should 1354
be absolutely, and without any condition restored to the King: answer also
was made to the reason of the Frenchmen, touching the oath of their King and
themselves, whereby they were bound to conserve the integrity of the honor of
their Kingdom, to weete, that the Pope for the benefit of peace might assoyle
them from the said oath, and this as to certain articles premitted, it
should be very well done: but yet nothing was done that might be offorce to
the furthering of the peace. And so the Embassadoures without effect returned
home, the Bishop of Norwich excepted, that deceassed, and was buried there, to
whom succeeded Thomas Percy.

The King of Navarre through a brawle raised, slew Charles de Spain, Marshall
of France, whereupon to avoid the displeasure and punishment of the French
King, he fled into his own Country, sending his Uncle unto the Duke of
Lancaster with Letters, humbly besieching him that he would come into
Normandy to his aid and defense, and to receive an oath of fidelity and
amity of him against all men. The Duke therefore getting license of the King,
assembled together a great Navy at Southampton, where when the Duke was ready
to have made Sail, Knights that he had sent into Normandy, came back to
view the truth of this business, by whom it was notifyed to the Duke, that
the said King of Navarre his Cousin, was reconciled to the King, and so the
Dukes voyage was stayde.

The Friars Augustines Church in London was reedified by Humfrey Bohun Earl of
Hereford and Estsex, whose Friar Augustines Church in London. To de Auesberie.
Dissension at Oxford. ^isto. Auria.
body was buried in the Quire of the same Church.

A great dissension fell in Oxford, between a Scholar and a Uintner, for a
quart of Wine, so that the Scholar poured the Wine on the Uintners head, and
brake his head with the pot, by reason whereof, a great conflict was made
betwixt the Scholars of the University, and the Lay men of the Town, in the
which, many Lay men were wounded, and about twenty slain. These troubles
continued the space of two days, and then the Religious men of the Town
laboring to make peace, the Lay men pursued a Scholar, and wounded him to
death, yet that day the tumult was appeased, but on the morrow, the people of
the Uillages about Oxford, being co^federate with the Lay men of the Town,
came with great force, and erected a black Banner, whereupon, the Scholars
fled to their Colleges, but the Lay me^ breaking up the doors, slew many of
them, and threw them into their priuies: they cut and rent their Books, and
bare away what they listed. By this means the University was dissolved, the
Scholars (saving of Marton College) went to their friends, and so continued
more than a year. Many, both Scholars and Lay men were endited Citizens of
Oxford endited.
by y^ Kings Justices, amongst y^ which, four burgesses y^ had bin Majors of
Oxford, were sent to the Tower of London.

William Totingham: Richard Smelt, the 28. of Septem. Sherifes. Mayor.


Thomas Leggy Skinner, the 28. of October.

About the xx. of November, K. Edward held a Parliament To. Auesbery.
at Westminster, in the which was granted toward the recovery of his title in
France, fifty Shillings of every sack of wool to be transported over the
Seas for the space of six years then next following, by means whereof, the
King might daily dispend during the said six years, more than 1000. marks
sterling, for by the common opinion, there were more tha^ an 100000. sackes of
wool yearly into foraigne lands transported, so that during those six
years, the said grant extended to fifteen hundred thousand pounds sterling.

King Edward held a great Justing at Wodstoke, for honor Anno reg. 29 Iusting
at VVodstock.
of the Queen, who was then purifyed of her son Thomas.

After Gaster, in a Parliament at Westminster, the King 1355
took the quarrel of Oxford into his hands, and saving every man's right, he
forgave the Scholars all the whole trespass, To. de Auesburie.
so that in the Summer following, the University began University of Oxford
restored.
again to flourish, and the King gave to the Chancellor of Oxford the only
view of the assise of Bread, Ale, and Wine, and all other victualles, excluding
the Mayor utterly from that office. The communaltie of the Town gave to the
University 250. pounds for amends, saving unto them nevertheless the actions
which they had unto every singular person of the Town.

In this Parliament, the process of the judgment made against Roger Mortimer
Earl of March, was revoked, so Ex Recordis.
that the young Roger Mortimer, son to Edmond Mortimer, was restored to the
title and possessions of the Earldom of March, as Cousin and heir to his
Grandfather.

King Edward being about Sandwich, on his journey toward King Edvvard^ sailed
into France.
France, and the Prince of Wales at Sutton in Devonshire, on his voyage
toward Aquitayne, looking for a prosperous wind, by the space of forty
days or more, all things else being ready, the French King had his armie^
divided in sundry places about in the Havens of Normandy, and other parts,
to empeach the landing of the King and Prince, and so long they lay there, that
the Frenchmen with their hired Souldioures did fowly wast their own Country,
and consumed so many thousands of Crowns out of the French Kings coffers
vaynely, that in the end he being needy, paid not his people, and so he was
forsaken of them, that when King Edward wasted France, the French King had not
men to encounter him, but fled before him, as he followed, brenning his own
Towns, and destroying victuals, that the King should find neither harborough
nor meat.

After the month of August, the King of England, and the Duke of Lancaster,
with seven thousand armed men, and their retinue, entered France, and by the
space of nine days journey, as they went, wasting all by fire that came in
their way, and returning to Caleis, the King heard that the Scots entered by
stealth, and had taken the Town of Berwike, the Bervvike taken by the Scotts.
Baron of Graystoke being in the army with the King, to whom the charge of
that Town had bin committed, whereupon the King hasted unto Berwike, and
within fifteen days recovered the Town again, being delivered Bervvike
taken by the Englishmen.
unto him, life and liberty to depart, being given unto them that were found
therein.

After this, he passed through Scotland unto the Scottish Sea, but because
victuals failed for his army, the King giving them license, they all returned
toward England. There followed on the tail of the army, by the space of
twelve miles, Robert Herle, Almerike de saint Edmond, Robert de Hildesley, and
other, whom the Scotts in the night season found asleep and at rest,
doubting nothing of any misaduenture, wherefore they gave a cruel assault
upon them, with an hideous noise and cry, where after long resistance, Robert
de Hildesley, and John Brancester Knights were taken prisoners, Robert Herle
and Almerike having much ado to escape, for the said Knights perceiving the
Scotts to be too strong for them, thought with themselves, that their Lords
being Barons, of whom they held in fee, would redeem them, and so wily
withdrawing, delivered them from the Scotts captivity.

The Duke of Lancaster being appointed chief Admiral of the English Navy,
landed it at Hogs about the feast of Saint Barthelmew, and from thence, rode
toward Normandy, being accompanied with Philip, brother to the King of
Navarre, who desired aid of the said Duke, and requested him to come to help
him. At this season, the French King having the King of Navarre, Geffrey
Harecourt, and diverse other noble men in great suspection, touching the Realm
and Kingdom, bid them all to a feast, where he took the said King of
Navarre, and cast him in prison, and murdered the rest of the noble men,
saving Geffrey Harecourt, whom he caused to be beheaded with an axe.

The King of Navarre being thus emprisoned, his brother Phillip seized many
Castles and holds into his hands which were in Normandy and there about,
strongly fortifying them with men and victualles, through the help of the Duke
of Lancaster, being manned as well with Englishmen, as with the men of the same
Country, to withstand the Frenchmen.

Walter Forester: Thomas Brandon, the 28. of Septem. Sherifes. Mayor.


Simon Frances Mercer, the 28. of October.

The same time, when the King passed over to Caleis and France, his eldest
son Prince of Wales, having with him the Earls of Warwike, Suffolk,
Salisburie, and Oxforde, took shipping in the beginning of October, at Sutton
Haven in Devonshire, and luckely sailed, and landed at Bordeaux, where he was
honorably received by the Bishop and Clergy, being accompanied with all the
common people in the first Sunday of that month. The Monday following, the
Prince going out, lodged two miles from Bordeaux, in the Castle of Vrnoun. On
the next day, he passed through a straight woodde, and so through the middle
of the Town of Lougan, sometimes walled, but now defaced: and so passing on a
long journey, he lost many Horses, and came at length to the strong Castle of
Dandert. On Thurseday he came to the City of Besas, having in it a Cathedral
Church, and a covent of Friars Minors. On Friday Proclamation was made in the
army, that every man should bear the arms of Saint George, and it was said
that his enemies bare the same also. On Saturday he passed to the Castle of
Nan, where stand three Castles of three Lords, whereof one shows a far
off. On Friday the twelfth of that month, his army passed the lands of
Wordiux, which are belonging to the Earl of Flux, this days journey being
long and tedious, he lost many of his Horses in the wast ground called the
Laundes. Two miles from the Town of Areule, he displayde his Banners, and
divided his armies into diverse troops. In the vaward, wherein was three
thousand men of arms, were the Earl of Warwike high Connestable, Reignold
Cobham, Lord Marshall, Lord Beawchamp, a Somersetshire man, the Lord Clifford,
and the Lord Thomas of Hampton, belonging to the Auntients, and with them
seven Barons of Gascoigne. In the middleward, wherein were seven thousand men
of arms, besides Clearkes and Pages, there was the Prince himself with a
double Ancient, the Earl of Oxford, the Lord Barthelmew Burwash, the Lord
John de Lile, the Lord Wilowby, the Lord Le Ware, ye Lord Maurice Barkeley,
son to Thomas Lord Barkeley then living, very old, the Lord John Boursers,
Lord John Rose the elder of Bordeaux, Captain de la Busch, the Lord Camount,
the Lord Mountferraunt, with their Auntients. In the rerewarde was four
thousand me^ of arms, committed to the charge of the Earl of Suffolk, the
Earl of Salisburie, and the Lord Nemers, who led the Bernences. In the whole
army was of me^ of arms, Clearkes, Pages, Archers, Brigants, and other, above
60000. men, and this day was Ienken Barefort, and diverse other made Knights,
and the village of Aurule, with three other villages (whereof Will. Lord Raymond
was Captain) were delivered up unto ye Prince, wherein he lodged his army, and
resting there two days, as many as would were suffered to go out, and took
victuals, and brenned their enemies country. On Tuesday, they lodged in ye
town of Mount Clear, where ye Castle belonging thereunto was given up to the
Prince, and after he left it again to the Frenchmen, by the reason of fire
which brake up in the town, whereupon, the Prince went out into the field, and
lodged in his tents, ever after refusing to lie in any town. This day having
taken three Towns, and brenning them, he made Knights Gilotus de Straton, and
diverse other. Also John de Lile stricken with a Quarrel at Austage, died. On
Wednesday and Thurseday he lay still, and on Friday he came before the strong
town of Loegeron, where he lodged in his tents. On Saturday he came before
Placence, a very fair town, and a strong, the inhabitants whereof fled away
into ye Castle, where the Earl of Molesni, and many Knights were taken by
Captain de la Bouch, and the Lord Mountferrant, and de Loachis, who was y^ day
made Knight. On Sunday S. Lukes day, they staid at Ewant, and taking the fort
of Galian by force, they set it on fire, and brent it. On Monday casting fire
in the towns of Placence, they passed along, leaving the town of Beal Marchi
on the right hand, and lodged before the Town of the Archbishop of Anfer,
called Le Base. On this day, Richard Stafford, brother unto the Earl of
Stafford, led his men with his Ancient toward ye town, and on the next day
being Tuesday, ye town was yielded unto him, and because it belo^ged to ye
Church, the Prince would not suffer any man to enter into it, excepting certain
persons appointed of purpose, for the delivering of victuals. On Wednesday they
leaving ye fair town of Escamount, on ye left hand, they came before the noble
town of Merand, belonging to ye Earl of Commege, which was full of armed
soldiers, and the Prince lodged in the great Monastery of Bartons, in ye
which Abbey, there was not so much as one living creature found. On Thurseday
they lay still, doing no harm to the said Abbey. On Friday they went out of
the fair and rich Country of Arminake, and entered the Country of Austerike,
through the which, the passage was very hard and hilly, and lodging at Saxaunt
a town, they set it on fire, contrary to the commandment of ye Prince. All that day, and three days following, they passed along by the high hills of
Aragon. On Saturday, they came to the town of S. More, where ye rereward of
the army lodged in a great Monastery of black Monks, which were all fled
away: the middleward at Vilfrankes, and the vaward at Tremaine: these villages
being very rich, and full of victualles, had no man in the^, for all the
inhabitants were fled. Sunday, the xxiiij. of October, they passed a certain
foord, and entered into the lands of ye Earl of Comenge, which reached unto
Tolouse, but these Countries were wasted with fire and sword, and leaving on the
left hand the Town called Sannetere in Austrike, they passed by the strong
City of Winbers, where Pope John the 22. removing the black Monks, erected a
Bishops sea, and they were lodged in a great and rich town called Sotanco,
belonging to ye Earldom of Comenge, where was a coue^t of friars Minors: and
burning this town, on Monday they passed through a goodly wide country, very
plain, and so came to the towns of S. Foy, and S. Litz. On Tuesday they
rested, and on Wednesday being the feast of Simon and Jude, the army passed
through ye River of Gerou^d, being a water very fierce, stony, and terrible:
and again the same day, through ye River of Arage, much more dangerous, and
came unto Tolouse: before that time, never durst any horsema^ pass over these
waters, wherefore ye people of this country being wonderfully made aferd,
could not tell what to do, for being sodeinly taken, they could not flee: that
night, the Prince lodged at Falgard, a little town, one mile from Tolouse. On
Tuesday, they came unto the fair and great town called Mount Gistard, being
part of the inheritance of the Lord Almerike de la Fossad, the which Town the
French King had taken from him, because he was ye King of Englands feed man.
Fast by the said Town were twelve Windmilles, the which they set on fire all
at once. There were taken two espies, that certified the Prince that the Earl
of Arminake was at Tolouse, and the Connestable of France at Mount Maban, four
leagues from Tolouse. On Friday, they passed on toward Auinion, by the good
town of Basige, and the town called Frank, and the whole army lodged at the
great Town called Auion^t, and the middleward and rereward lay in one side of
the suburbs, and the vaward lay on the other side of the Town, which the
Townsmen perceiving, fled every one. There was about this Town twenty
Windmilles, which they set on fire. On Saturday the last of October, they
lodged in the great Town called Clastalnannar, where a Church of Chanons, a
coue^t of Friars Minors, and another of Carmelites, with an Hospital, and a
Uillage called Les mauns de Pucels, with a covent of Friars Augustines, were al
consumed with fire. On Sunday, the feast of All Saints, the army rested, out
of the which army, certain going to take booties, they took a little town,
the inhabitants whereof to be spared from spoiling, gave them x. M. Florens of
gold. On monday, they marched along by the Towns of S. Mathele Port, and the
great Town called Vilkapinch, and from thence, they entered the Country of
Carkason, and the Prince lodged at a little Uillage called Alse. On Tuesday
they came to Carkason, a fair town, rich and well built, bigger than London.
Within the walls, betwixt the town of Senburge, and the City being double
walled, there ran a goodly water, which passed under a fair stone Bridge, at
the foot whereof, were four couents of Religions, of ye which, the Friars ran
not away, but the other fled into the City. The whole army was lodged in the
town, which abounded with Muskadell, and all other delicate victuals: this
day, the sons of the Lord Libret, and Master Basset, with Rowland Daues, and
many other, were made Knights. On Wednesday and Thurseday, the army lying
still in the Town, and having made a truce, they parlied with them of the
City concerning a peace, the Citizens Carkason in France burned.
offering for saving the Town from burning 250000. of golden Souses: the
Prince answered, he came not for gold, but to take Cities and Towns, together
with their inhabitants, and the next day commanded the Town to be brent. On
Friday, the Town being brent, the army departed, leaving on the left hand the
Castle of Botenake untouched, passing through the champion Country, burning
Towns called La Rustican, and all the Country thereabout. On Saturday they
trauayled through a great wind and dust, leaving on the left hand a great
poole of fresh water, being in compass about thirty leagues, and is called
Casibon. They came to a Town called Silony, which was yielded to the Prince,
and therefore never touched: and the Prince was lodged that night at a good
Town called Canet. On Sunday the eight of November, they passed the water of
Sandey, partly at the Foord called Chastel de Terre, and partly over a Bridge,
and so trauayled betwixt high hills, unto the great City of Narbon, whereof
that Country taking his name, is called Gallia Narbonensis. This City was
very strong, and well walled, having in it a great Cathedral Church: also, a
notable Castle, belonging to the Bishop, and a very strong Tower for the Earl
of the same Town. It had also a Suburb called a Borough, much bigger, and
better built, than the Borough of Carkason. In the Borough, were four Couents
of Religious persons. Betwixt the Borough and the City, there runs a water
called Ande, coming from Carkason, and runs into the Greekish Sea. Betwixt
the City and the Borough are two Bridges of stone, and the third of timber,
built with storehouses for diverse Merchandises. The Prince was lodged in the
house of Carmelite Friars. On Tuesday the Borough being set on fire, the army
passing to the water side, went over it in diverse places. From thence, they
went and lodged at the Town and Castle of Ambion. On Wednesday they traveled
an evil journey, and hurtful to the Horse for lack of water. On Thurseday,
Theodorike Dale, Porter of the Princes Chamber, was made Knight: thence the
Army passed by a good town called Vlmes: the middleward passed unto the good
Town of the Earl of Lile, called Arnile, where they lodged that night. The
Prince lay at the Friars Minors, where was great abundance of Muskadell,
being provided for the Countess of the I Will, which was all spoiled. This day
also, the good Town of Pipions was destroyed, with the Castle thereof called
Redote. On Friday, the army passing by a long stony way, lodged at Lamian. On
Saturday, returning back toward Gascoigne, they left on their right hand the
great poole of Esbone, and Carkason, and all the journey that they went
before, and the rereward lodged at a good Town called Abier, and the
middleward at Puch^iancies, where a Castle being defended, withstoode them a
season, but at length was won, and the Prince lay beyond the Bridge, by a
fair running water, on both sides whereof, the Country was spoiled with fire,
together with the good Town of Pesaunce, where the vawarde was lodged y^
night. On Sunday they traveled a* long journey, because the Prince should be
lodged in the great Abbey of our Lady de Prolion, where in several Cloisters,
did live 100* Predicants, whereunto, the Prince was deuoutely received. In y^
day, the army set on fire ye town of Lemeins, where there was far greater
Couents of Religions, than at Carkason. Also, they brent the fair Town called
Falanges, unto which town belonged xxj. Windmilles. They brent also the towns
of Vnlard, and Serre, with all ye whole Country lying theraboutes. On Monday
the middleward lodged at the good town called Dealpuhbon, which long time was
defended, but at length gotten by force, the Castle whereof yielded, unto the
which Town and Castle, the Prince commanded that no harm should be done by
fire. On Tuesday early passing over ye river of Beseile, they entered into a
country which was broad. About one aclocke, they came before a great Abbey
called Bourgbon, where the Earl of Fluxens with great joy received the Prince,
he being newly escaped out of prison from Paris, where he had lain by the
space of two years: and the said Earl remained from that time faithful to the
Prince. This day they rode in the Lordships and seigniories of the same Earl,
by the Towns of Masell and Colmon, and on the right hand they passed by the
great Town of Saint Canole, and the high Castle called Hautripe: but on this
day they brent nothing for reverence of the foresaid Earl and his Uineyards,
but passed again over the water of Arage, leaving also Tolous as they did at
the first: but then one mile on the left hand, and now four leagues on the
right, and the middle ward was lodged in the great Town of Mermount, which
together with the Castle was brent. On Wednesday, they passed by the Castle
of the Earl of Flux* called Mounthane, at the foot whereof, all the horsemen
passed over the great water of Geround, and there took the Town and Castle
of North, then leaving the River of Gerond on the left hand, and so passed unto
the town of Marconaw, which they took: then they returned over the River
again, and took the strong Town of Carbone. On Thurseday ye army rested. On
Friday word was brought to the Prince that the French were up, and had gathered
a great force, which they had divided into five great battles, being in the
field not far from them, wherevpo^ our men set themselves in battle array,
about one mile from the place where they lodged, and being now ready to
fight, some one of the Souldioures by chance start a Hare, whereupon a great
shout was made, which the enemies hearing, they sent out forty light
Horsemen, to see what was the cause thereof, who drawing nigh to the English
army, and perceiving them to be set in battle array, returned back again,
and declared what they had seen: whereupon presently the whole army of
Frenchmen fled with great fear. The same day, Barthelmew Burwash, John
Chandos, and James de Audley, with xxiiij. light horsemen, were appointed
scoutes, and coming to y^ tail of y^ Frenchmen, they took prisoners xxxij.
Knights and gentlemen, amongst whom, they took the Earl of Romeme, also they
slew many Carters and Wagoners. The Prince lodged in ye town of Muwose. On
Saturday they marched to the Castle of Oradrie, in which Castle the Prince
lodged, and in the morning they brent it. On Sunday the two and twentieth of
November, about evening, they perceived that their enemies were on the other
side of ye great Hill hard by the great town of Gemount, so that the English
men being be-nighted, sent out. lx. light horssemen, and certain bowmen unto
the right hand of the town called Auremount, where finding. 400. men of
arms of the Conestable of France, they chased them out of the Town, and
slew and took many: the middle Ward lodged at Auremount, and the Uawarde at
Colimont. Earelye in the morning the Wagoners being commanded to remain in
the Town of Auremount, all the residue being divided into troops, went into
the field, waiting for the coming of their enemies, all in vain: for the
Prince taking the Town of Gamount, was told that his enemies fled away at
midnight. On Twesday the army lodged in the field, and for lack of Water,
their horse were feign to drink Wine, whereof it came to pass, that the
next day their horses were so drunk they could not go right forth, and
many of them dyed. On Saint Katherines day, with much a do they came to
Water, and leaving the Town of Florence on their right hand, they passed to
the great town called Silard, and the middle ward was lodged at a Town
called Realmount, which they took by maine force, and therefore brent it. On
Thursday they rested. On Friday they trauayled a long journey, by Walled towns
and strong Castles, the middle ward lodged at Serde. On Saturday they passed
over a certain Water with great difficulty, and through woods, till they came
to a good Town called Mesin. On Sunday the Prince rested, and took homage and
oaths of the Townsmen. Monday Saint Andrews day traveling a long journey,
they came to the Town of Tolows, where were three Castles. On Twesday the
prince traveled to the Castle of Melan, where he lodged. On Wednesday the
Prince came to Regla, where his horses and Wagons passed through the river of
Gerond. In this Anno reg. 30
town of Regla, the Prince appointed diverse Barons and such like to Winter
in diverse places of the Marches, to the intent they should keep the inland
parts of Gascoigne against the French men.

The Prince of Wales touching these matters aforesaid, and for other
considerations also, caused a new coin of gold to be made in Gascoigne,
being busied himself about the repayring of such things as were decayed and
thrown down. And in this season, there sprang up a foolish fantasy in the
French men's heads, that the King of England was come into Normandy, the
cause of which rumor rose up, for that the Duke of Lancaster, after that he
had fortifyed the strong places belonging to the King of Nauar, which were in
the I Will of Constance and other places, did direct his journey toward
Brytaine, whereof he was newly made chief Captain. Another cause was this,
Phillippe brother to 1356
the King of Nauar, came into England, and earnestly craved aid of the King,
against the French King, who kept his brother in prison, that he might by
force of arms restoare all such lands unto him as were wrongfully withholden
from him, whereupon he offering to do homage and fealty, he had (of the
Kings appoyntmente,) Miles Stapleton, a man of great integrity, and in
martial affairs very skilful, him (I say) the king appointed to be his
faithful fellow. These men with two thousand men well appointed traveling
through Normandy, took towns and Fortresses, burning diverse of them,
passing along till they came to a Castle nine leagues distaunte from the City
of Paris: neither did they a^lake their travail, until they had forced their
enymies to enter into a yearelye truce. By this means a great report and no
less fear filled the hearts of all French men, which report at length came
to the ears of the Prince lying at Regla, wherefore he gathering all the power
he had with him in his Dukedom, to the intent to meet his Father, which he
must do by traveling through France, he came at length to Brugetat, where
he was certifyed that the Earl of Armenia, would after his departure have
spoiled the Country, and for that intent had provided a great band of men:
wherefore he sent back to the governor of Gascoigne, unto Barnarde de
Libret, and other. From thence the prince went into France, through the coasts
of Barny and Lymon, still encouraging his men against their enemies, sending
before him John Chandos, James Dawdeley, and other accomplices, to try out the
state of their enemies country, least perhaps some crafty ambushment might
suddenly assault our men, before they were ware. He himself removing his camp
every day, and now being entered into Pictauia, his espies brought word that
the French king had gathered a great army, being now in Aurelian, who also
knew of the Princes coming, for he sent out espies to discover our army,
amongst who^ Griffin Micco of Chambly, petie Captain of two hundred men,
meeting with other espies, came to his coaste: for our espies took thirty of
the^, and slew the residue, so that there was not one of them left to carrye
word what was become of their fellows. Our espies proceeded toward
Romerentine, where meeting with the Lord Crone, and Lord Brisgande, they set
upon them and slew them, their chief Captains being forced to flee to a
castle, and having taken their lodging in a town, the prince commanded that on
the morning a great assault should be given to the^ of ye Castle. The day
following our men being al armed, passed through the ditches, and came unto ye
walls of the Castle, some applied to scale ye wall with ladders, some burn the
gates, and entering, slew a great many of the chief men, but ye Lords before
named fled unto the principal tower of ye castle: but ye prince determined not
to depart, til they that were besieged, were either taken or yielded: at length
the Castle being undermined, the men besieged, with all humility yielded up
the Castle. After this the spies declared that the French King was come down
to Turon, to provide armies to go against the Prince, of the which tidings the
Prince being glad, he pighte his tents against the French King, but could
not pass the river of Ledger, by reason of great floudes, and the French King
had broken all the bridges, to the intent there should be no passage
betwixt the Prince and the Duke of Lancaster, whose armies might well every
night perceive each others fires in the Camps: but the Prince following
along the river of Legers Eastwarde, he pyghte his tents near unto Turon,
where loking for the French King four days, hoping to fight with him, for
that he was distaunte but one league off, he understood that the French King
was retired back to Blamia, ten leagues off: passing over by a Bridge the
River of Legers at a place used betwixt two strong Towns, and so toward
Poyters. This retyring of the French king certifyed, the Prince returned
back, intending to have met him in his way, which he could not do: yet
crossing over all, as he imagined the nerer way, he set upon the tail of his
enymies, and cut from them the Earls of Inyni and Winters, and also the
Marshall of Burgonie, these being taken, died, as was thought, through the
great toil they had taken: night drawing on, our men gave themselves to rest
in a wood, intending the next day to take their journey toward Poiters, and by
the way they were certifyed that the French King, with great provision
prepared himself to battle, and drew nigh to our tents: The Battle of
Poyters.
the Prince therefore committed the vawarde of the army to the Earls of
Warwick and Oxford, the middle ward was guided by the Prince, and the rerewarde
was led by the Earls of Salisburie and Suffolk. In all the whole army of the
Prince there was not above four thousand men of arms, one thousand armed
soldiers, and two thousand Archers. The pompous nobility of the French men
drew nygh, greatly disdayning the small company of the English men, for they
had in number eight thousand fighting soldiers, they had also seven
auntients. At this matter a great many of our men murmured, because of late, a
great part of our army was sent to defend Gascoigne. There was among the
French men a certain Scotte called William Douglas, a man of great force and
practice in the Wars: this manne did the French king make Knight, and because
he knew he would be a deadly enemy to the English men, he gladlye hearkened
to his aduices. This William was Captain over two hundred Scotts: these men
understood well that it was the custom of the English men in those days to
fight on foot, in which point they followed the Scotts, and the Scots also
provoked the French king and other French men to fight in like manner. The
French king obeying his foolish counsel, gladly agreed unto his sayings,
whereupon he sent light horssemen into the City, that they should suffer
no man to make any chase, but only. 500. horssemen well appointed to come out
against the Archers, in the beginning of the conflict, and to run them over
and to tread them under their horse feet: but these performed not that
which was commanded them, as it appeared by the sequel thereof. The armies
being set in a readiness on both sides for to fight early on Sunday in the
morning, which was notable fair, behold there came the Cardinal of
Petragoren, and charged the prince, in the name of God who was crucified, that
it might please him to defer the war for a time, both for ecclesiastical
peace, and also for the sparing of Christian blood, and to the end there might
be a treaty had of peace, the which he promised should be performed with
great honor on both sides. The Prince neither feared nor refused peace, but
modestly agreed to the request of this Father. All this day now being
appointed for the obtaynyng of peace, the army of the French men increased by
the number of a thousand men of arms, and also of other. On the morrow
after, the Cardinal came again from the French king, in his behalf to
request a truce, which should endure for one whole year, the which the Prince
denied, yet at the importunate suit of that Cardinal, he granted a truce to
continue till Christmasse next coming. Therefore the Cardinal returning to
the French King, requested him of pledges for the truce, but the Marshall
Dawdenam, Geffrey de Charney, and Douglas the Scot, persuaded him that by
common reason it could not come to pass that the English men should at that
time prevail, and especially, because they were but few, and in a strange
Country, and wearyed out miserably with their toil in travel, and therefore
not ableto endure so great a number of the French men of France, who stood in
defense of their own land. The Prince of Wales being certified, that the
Captains of the French, would have no kind of peace, but such as they could get
by force of arms, and calling his men together, he made to them an Oration
first in general, and then to his Archers as follows: your ma^hoode (says
he) has bin always known to me, in great dangers, which shows yt you are
not degenerate from true sons of English men, but to be descended from the
blood of them which heretofore were under my fathers dukedom, and his
predecessors kings of England, unto whom no labor was paineful, no place
invincible, no ground impassable, no Hill (were it never so high) inaccessible,
no tower vnscaleable, no army inpenitrable, no armed soldier, or whole hosts
of men was formidable. Their lively couragiousnesse tamed the French men, the
Ciprians, the Siracusians, the Galabrians, and the Plestinis, and brought under
the stiff necked Scotts, and unruly Irish men, yea and the Walsh men also,
which could well endure all labor. Occasion, time, and dangers, makes of
fearful, very strong and stout, and does many times of dull witted men
make witty: honor also, and love of the Country, and the desire of the rich
spoil of the French men, does stir you up to follow your fathers steps*
Wherefore follow your auntients, and wholly be intentive to follow the
commandment of your Captains as well in mind as in body, that if victory
come with life, we may still continue in firm friendship together, having
always one will, and one mind: but if envious Fortune (which God forbid)
should let us at this present, to run the race of all flesh, and that we
end both life and labor together, be you sure that your names shall not want
eternal fame and heavenly joy, and we also with these gentlemen our
companions, will drink of the same cup, that you shall do, unto whom it shall
be an eternal glory and name, to have won the nobility of France: but to
overcome (as God forbid) is not to be ascribed unto the danger of time, but to
the courage of the men. Having spoken these words, he perceived that there was
a Hill hard by, which was planted on the top with hedges and ditches, the
inside whereof was very plain, and a pasture field on the one side thereof,
with many roughe bushes, and on the other side it was all planted with vines,
and the residue was plain, in the top whereof he did imagine the army of the
French to lie betwixt our men and the Hill. There was great and low vallyes, and
a piece of marish ground. One company of the Prince finding out a narrow
passage, entered the valley and took the Hill, where among the bushes they hid
themselves, taking the advantage of the place. The field wherein our men lay,
to wit, the vawarde and middle ward, was divided from the plain where the
French army lay, with a long hedge and ditche, the one end whereof did
reach down to the Marishe aforesaid: that of the Hill next the Marishe, the
Earl of Warwick kept, Captain of the vawarde. In the upper part of the
hedge, toward the hanging of the Hill, there was a great gap, from the which a
stones cast stood our rereward, over the which the Earl of Salisburie was
Captain. Our enymies perceyuyng our Princes auntiente to be displayed, and
ofttymes to be removed from place to place, and by reason of the Hill to be
some time quite out of sight, they judged that the Prince fled, yet Douglas
the Scotte and Marshal de Clarimount, said that it was not so, but Marshal
Dawdenam being deceived in his own opinion, thought otherwise, crying out
still to follow and chase the Prince now fleeing, and with him also Douglas,
to the intent to get preferment and a worthy name of his new warfare: but
Clarimount to wash away the evil opinion which was conceived of him
touching his fidelity, was the more vehement to persuade them forward, for
unto them the charge of the vawarde was deputed: before these went out, as the
fashion was, certain to chase and to just, against whom certain that were
under the Hill of our vaward came to meet Marshal Dawdenam, who staying to see
the end of the iusting, kept himself from encountering. In the mean time
Clearimount thinking to come out by the gap in the hedge, and so to come at the
back of our vawarde, and to compass them in, met with the Earl of
Salisburie, who perceiving his coming and purpose, suspected his whole intent,
and so they which governed our rereward, making haste to take the gap, and
keep the enemy from passing that way, sustained the first charge of the
battle. Then began a terrible meeting betwixt the armed men, who laid on
load with swords and spears, neither did the Archers slack their duty,
but lying in safe trenches, start up above the ditche and shot over the hedge,
preuayling more with their arrows, than they did that fought in arms: thus
our rerewarde slaying the enemies, who came straggling to the gap, and the
vawarde which lay on the hanging of the Hill, toward the Marish, being governed
by the Earl of Warwick, were always ready and met with the French men,
beating them down. The Archers of the vawarde were placed in the Marishe, out
of danger from the horssemen, yet for all that they did prevail there
somewhat, for ye horsemen were appointed to no other purpose but to ouerrunne
the Archers. The Earl of Oxforde considering the discommodity that might ensue
thereof, departed from the Princes ward, and leading with him the Archers, set
them on the one side of the French men, commanding them to shoot at yt hinder
parts of the horses, by means whereof the horses being gauld and wounded,
fell to tumbling with them that sat on their backs, or else turned back and
ran upon them that followed after, making great slaughter upon their own
masters. The horssemen being thus beaten back, the Archers retired toward
the place from whence they came, shooting and gauling the sides of the French
men which fought right over against them: by this time the force and heat of
the battle began to be in prime, when as the Earls of Warwick and
Salisburie, like fierce Lions endeavored of purpose which of them should dung the
land of Poyters most with French men's blood. Nether was the wise Counselor
Thomas Dassord of Suffolk idle at that season, who right worthylie in all his
acts behaved himself, being expert and skillful in actiuitie. For he
continually running from ward to ward, and into all troops and companies,
comforted and styrred them up with good words to do well, having a great
regard that the youthful sort of lusty soldiers being to bold upon
their good hearts and courage, should not without regard go out too far,
and placed the Archers at sundry times to great advantages, and oftentimes as
leisure would suffer him, he would encorage up the minds of the soldiers.
Clarimount was slain, William Douglas also being wounded fled, having with
him a few Scots of his band, with Archebald Douglas his brother: our men
retiring, put themselves in good array, and our vaward and midle-warde joined
themselves together, by and by there marches forth a new army of the French
men, the which the eldest son of the French king, Dolphin of Vienna, brought
forth. The order and array of this army was more terrible and fierce than the
show of that which was last oppressed, yet for all that could not it make our
men afraid, who were sharp set, and very desirous of honor, and also of
revenge, both for themselves, and their fellows, which a little before were
slain and wounded. And therefore boldly they go to it on both sides, making
showts and noyses, crying out, Saint George to borrow, or Saint Denis be for
us. Within a while they were come to fight man to man, and every man ready to
die, fight now to save their lives, neither does ye Lion make the Wolf afraid,
or the Tegre is more terrible to the simple beast, than our lusty gentlemen
were to their enemies, who chaced them, and slew them like as the Wolves chase
and kill Sheep. And though that this battle withstood our men more than the
first, yet, after they had lost a great many of their men, they had such a
devise, that they saved many, and yet, not by running away, but by a fair
retreat, which the Frenchmen are accustomed to use. But our men considering,
that the victory of the field was doubtful, as long as the French King might
be in presence with his army, who lay there half hid in a Ualley, they would
not afterward, when they had chaced any that fled, go out of the field, but the
worthy man Maurice Barkley, son of Thomas Barkley, had no regard there unto,
who for ye space of two hours together with his men, never spared, but would be
still in the forefront of the battle, inuading his enemies with the first, This
Maurice being in ye midst of y^ Dolphens guard sowed blows among them, first
with a spear, than with a sword, and at length he being al alone compassed with
the multitude, and forely wounded, he was taken prisoner. In the mean time our
me^ carried those which were wounded of their camp, and laid the^ under bushes
and hedges out of y^ way, other having spent their weapons took y^ spears and
swords from them who^ they had overcome: and the Archers lacking arrows, made
have to draw them from pore wretches y^ were but half dead: there was not one
of the^ all, but either he was wounded or quite wearied with great labor,
except. 400. me^ who keeping yt chief standart, were appointed to meet y^
French king. The Dolphin being thus put to flight, one came to y^ French K.
and said, my Lord K. the field is fallen to the English men, and your eldest
son has withdrawn himself: unto who^ y^ French King answered with an oath, y^
he would not y^ day forsake y^ field unless he were taken or slain, and so by
y^ means carried away by force: wherefore the auntiente bearers are comanded to
march forwards, after who^ followed two great co^panyes of armed me^ into a wide
field, showing themselves to our men, and struck a great fear into their
hearts, in so much y^ they were out of hope to conquire any more. The which
thing a man of great wisdom standing by ye prince signified with a howling
voice, (saying alas we poor wretches are overcome,) but the prince having a
great trust and says in Christ, checked him, saying, thou lie thou dastardly
fellow, for thou can not say yt we can be overcome as long as I live. Captain
de la Buche, a noble man in all affairs, as soon as he perceived the arms of
the French King, marching forth of their tents, asking license of the Prince
departed away with lx. soldiers, and a hundred Archers, whom many of our men
thought to have fled away: wherefore our soldiers (excepting the chief
Captains) being quite out of hope of victory, committed themselves wholly to
the mercy of God. Then the Prince commanded his Ancient bearer sir Walter
Woodland, to march foreward toward his enemies, and with a^ew fresh men he joined
battle with ye great army of the French king: by and by they sound their
trumpets, one giving answer to another, they made such a noise y^ the Walls of
Poyters sou^ded with the Echo thereof like a wood, in such sort y^ a man would
have thought y^ the hills had bellowed out to ye valleys, and that ye clouds had
given forth a most terrible thu^der, to ye which there wa^ted no cruel
lightnings, whylest the air shone on ye bright armor and spears dashing
against shining harneis. The^ came on the cruel company of crosbowme^, making a
darkness in y^ s^ies with yt multitude of quarrels which they shot, against
who^ came a worthy company of English bowmen: out flies also Darts of Ash
which met with the enemy afar off: but ye French army being full of diverse troops,
and many armed me^ defe^ding their breasts with their shields, proceed forward
against their enemies: wherefore our Archers having emptied their quiuers in
vain, being armed only with swords and Targets, are fayn to encounter with them
that were laden with armor. Then bestirreth himself the worthy Prince of
Wales, cutting and hewing the French men with a sharp sword. In the mean time
Captain de la Buch marches a compass about, under the hangyng of the Hill,
which he with the Prince a little before forsook, and privily compassing about
the field, at the length comes close under the place where the French Camp
lay, from thence he ascended to the top of the Hill that way, which the
French men had beaten with their travail, and so suddenly breaking forth
unlooked for, and showing by the ensign of Saint George that he was our friend,
the Prince with great courage gives a fresh charge on the French army, being
desirous to break their ranckes, before the captain aforesaid, should set
on the side of the battle. The Prince lustilye encountering with his enemies
goes into the middle of the throng, and where he sees most company there he
lays about him on every side.

In the mean time on the other side, his friends which served with Captain de
la Buche, were at the backs of the enemies, beating down and killing without
pity, and the Archers also placed for the purpose shot so thick, wounding the
backs and sides of the French men, in such sort, that the form of the
battle was quite spoiled, neither could they put themselves in order or array
any more. This was the courage of the Prince, who at the lenghth thrusts
thorough the throngs of them, that guarded the French King, then should you
see an ancient begin to nod and stumble, the bearers of them to fall down,
the blood of flaues and Princes ran mingled together into the waters which
were nigh. In like sort the Bore of Cornwall rages, who seeks to have none
other way to the French Kings standard, tha^ by blood only: but when they came
there, they met with a ^o^pany of stout men to withstand them, the English me^
fight, the French men also lay on, but at length Fortune making have to turn
her wheel, the Prince preaceth forewarde on his enemies and like a fierce Lion
beating down the proud, he came to yielding up of the French King. The French
men being scattered abroad in the fields of Poycers perceiving that the
standard with the flouerdeluce was beaten down, fled with all speed toward
the Town, which was not far off, the English men perceiving them to be
fleeing, though themselves were either sore wounded or wearied, followed them
in chase even to the gates of Poyters where in a great skirmishe and very
dangerous, they slew a great number of French men. At the last our me^ being
called back by retreat with ye sound of trumpet, and assembling together,
there were diverse Pauilians and tents set up in the fields, and the whole
company being throughlye comforted with this victory, gave their whole
endeavor to provide for them that were wounded, for the quiet rest of them
that were wearied, for safe keeping of them that were taken prisoners, and for
the refreshing of them that were almost famished, until they had full
understanding who and how many were wanting, among them which were found half
dead, was found the Lord James Dawdeley, by reason of his broad bucklet, and
being carried in the arms of his soldiers, was brought to the Princes
lodging, and the Prince himself rise from his supper, and came to him, and
caused him to be stripped and laid in a soft bed, and being somewhat better
come to his remembrance, the Prince comforted him, swearing unto him that he
had the French King yielded unto him, which news when the languishing Noble
man heard, he straight ways revived. The Prince returning to the French King,
willed him not to deny that to be an unworthy deed of his that rose from his
supper to comfort him that was almost dead, who spared not his own blood to
purchase victory. After that they having had some talk concerning the wars
which James Dawdeley made, the French king said that amongst all other
stout Champions, which valiauntly that day behaved themselves, he did greatly
wonder at the noble deeds of that knight, and he spoke not much more in all
his supper, but what he spoke to the Prince, who comforted his noble pray.
Such like words, it is said that the French king spoke: Although it be our
chance to fall into an everlasting sorrow, yet for all that we thought it
good to refrain from the same by a kind of measure, for though we be under
subjection by law and right of war under our noble cousin, yet are we not as
rascals, or faint hearted runne-awayes, or taken lying hid close in a corner,
but after the manner of the field by the end and success of war, where we
were as ready to dye as live for justice sake. And in the same field were
many richmen taken, whose lives were reserved for ransom, the fainte hearted
and lewd chased away, but the worthyest and stoutest were spoiled of their
lives. This battle of Poyters was fought on the nineteenth day of September.

The next day after the battle, all the prisoners were numbered, to wit the
French king, also Phillip his son, the Archbishop of Senon, the Earl of
Pontue, the Earl of Longuile* the Earl of Ewe, the Earl of Tankeruile, the
Earl Daunter, the Earl of Vendadour, the Earl of Slauncer, the Earl of
Wademount, the Earl of Vandome, the Earl of Iuyny, the Earl Don Martin, the
Earl of Selabruse, the Earl of Sasso, Vicount Nerbon, the Lord Daubeny,
Marshal Dawdenam, the Lord Guinc^arde de Angle, Seneshal de Seintong, the Lord
Mores Mawnimet, the Lord Leonard de Guilhoy, the Seneshal of Poyters, the Lord
great Master, the chief master of the Hospital of Spaigne, the Lord of
Saint Tigre, the Lord Damboyd Seneshal of Annar, the Lord Tower, the Lord
Dars, the Lord Durual, the Lord of the Town of Ernell, the Lord Maugeler,
the Lord Planke, the Vicount de Belimount, and the Lord of Suly: there were
also the bodies found of many that were slain, as the Duke of Burbon, the
Duke Dasines, the Conestable of France, Marshal de Garimount, the Lord
Geffrey de Charney, the Lord Pounce, y^ Bishop of Chaloner, the Lord of
Laundas, yt Lord Ripemou^t* the Lord Chaneny, the Lord Io^e, the Lord Nele,
the Lord Aunger, the Lord de Mount John, the Lord Dargenton, the Lord Groose,
the Lord Ruas, the Lord Rochechicheward, the Lord de Vilem. The Prince bought
all the prisoners and Captives of them that kept them, and carried them with
him to Bordeaux, there to remain in safe custody, during his abode there.

Richard Notingham: Thomas Dossel, the. 28. of Septem. Sherifes. Mayor. ^^ 1^57
Anno reg. 21


Henry Picarde Vintener, the. 28. of October.

Edward Prince of Wales returning into England with John the French King,
Phillip his son and many other prisoners, arrived at Plymouth* on the fifth of
May, and the. 24. of May entered London with them, where he was received with
great honor of the Citizens, and so conuayed to the kings pallaice at
Westminster, where the King sitting in his estate in Westminster Hall, received
them, and after conveyed the French King to a lodging, where he lay a season:
and after the said French King was lodged in the Sauoy, (which then was a
pleasant place belonging to the Duke of Lancaster.) In the Winter following
were great and royal iustes holden in Smithfielde at London, where many knightly
sights of arms were done, to the great honor of the king and realm, at the
which were present the Kings of England, France, and Scotland, with many
noble estates of all those Kingdoms, whereof the more part of the strangers
were prisoners.

Henry Picarde Uintener, Mayor of London, in one day did sumptuouslye feast
Edward King of England; John King of France, the King of Cipres (then
arrived in England) David king of Scotts, Edward Prince of Wales, with many
noble men and other, and after the said Henry Picarde kept his Hall against
all comers who soever, that were willing to play at Dice and Hazard. In like
manner the Lady Margaret his wife did also keep her Chamber, to the same
intent. The King of Cipres playing with Henry Picarde in his Hall, did win
of him 50. marks, but Henry being very skillful in that art, altering his
hand did after win of the same king, the same. 50. marks, and 50. marks
more, which when the same king began to take in ill part, although he
dissembled the same, Henrye said unto him, my Lord and King be not agrieued, I
covet not your gold but your play, for I have not bid you hither that I might
grieve you, but that amongst other things I might try your play, and gave him
his money again, plentifully bestowing of his own amongst the retinue:
besides he gave many rich gifts to the King and other Nobles and Knights,
which dyned with him, to the great glory of the Citizens of London in these
days.

Stephen Candish: Barthelmew Frostling, the. 28. of Sep. Sherifes. Mayor.


Sir John Stody Vintener, the. 28. of October.

This sir John Stody gave unto the Uinteners of London all the quadrant wherein
the Uinteners Hal now stands with the tenements round about, from the lane
yet called Studis Lane, where is founded thirteen houses for xiij. poor
people which are there kept of charity rent free.

About Halowntide, David le Bruce king of Scots was delivered from the long
imprisonment of a. xj. years, in the castle of Oldiham, his ransom being set,
a 100000. marks to be paid the next ten years following.

Normandy and Brytaine were soar spoiled and wasted Tho. Walsing. Anno reg.

into three parts, committed one company unto Henry Duke King Edward invaded

Simon Dolseby Grocer, the 28. of October.

King Edward with his power rode through France, by Picardie, Artois, Roan,
Champaine, and so to Briteine, destroying the Country before him. And here is
to be noted, that the fourteenth day of April, and the morrow after Easter
day, King Edward with his host lay before the City of Paris, which day was
full dark of mist and hayle, and so bitter cold, that many men died on their
Horse backs with the cold, wherefore unto this day it has bin called the
black Monday. The King of Navarre vexed sore the marches of Normandy. Thus
was the Realm of France miserably beset on all sides. At the last, a final
peace was concluded on Peace with France.
this condition, that King Edward should have to his possession, the Countries
of Gascoine, Gwyen, Poytiers, Limosin, Baleuile, Exantes, Caleis, Gwisnes, and
diverse other Lordships, Castles, Towns, and all the Lands to them belonging,
Tho. Walls.
without knowledge of any sovereignty or subjection for the same. This peace
being confirmed by writing and by oath, King Edward came into England, and so
straight to the Tower to see the French King, where he appointed his ransom
to be three millions of Florences, and so delivered French King releassed.
him of all imprisonment, and brought him with great honor to the Sea, who
then*sayled over into France.

John Denis: Walter Berney, the 28. of September. Sherifes. Mayor.


John Wroth Fishmonger, the 28. of October.

King Edward the 24. of Januarie began a Parliament at Westminster, where the
form of the agreement was read, and allowed of all estates, where the King on
the last of Januarie caused his Nobles to swear to hold and Anno reg. 35 1361
keep the said agreement, especially those as well Prelates as other that were
not at Caleis, where he swear, and other that were there with him.

A great dearth and pestilence happened in England, which was called the second
pestilence, in which died Henry D. of Lancaster The second mortality.
in March at London, and was buried at Leycester, in the colegiate Church which
he had founded, with a Deane, twelve Chanons, Prebendaries, as many Uickers,
and other ministers accordingly.

There dyed also Reginald Lord Cobham, and Walter Lib. Lichfield.
Fitz Waren, valiant and famous Knights, and five Bishops, to weete, Reginald
of Worcester, Michael of London, Thomas of E^lie, John of Lincoln, and Robert
of Cicester. To Worcester was preferred John of Barnet: to London, Simon
Sudburie: to Ely, Simon Langham: to Lincoln, John Bokingham: to Cicester,
William Linlinere.

Leonell Earl of Hulster by his wife, and son to King Edward, went into
Ireland to recounter the Irishmen that vexed the English.

Edward Prince of Wales took to wife by dispensation the Countess of Kent,
daughter unto Edmond Earl of Kent, brother to King Edward the second: she had
bin before wife unto Thomas Holland and before that, she was wife to the Earl
of Salisburie, and divorced from him.

A route of the great company of the Englishmen were commanded to depart out of

John Peche Fishmonger, the 28. of October.

The King held his Christmas at Windsore, and the xv. day following, a sore and
vehement Southweast wind brake forth, so hideous, that it overthrew high
Houses, Towers, Steeples, and Trees, and so bowed them, that the residue which
fell not, but remained standing, were the weaker.

Stephen Candish Draper, the 28. of October.

The sixteenth day of October, began a Parliamente at London, which continued
till the feast of Saint Brice, the thirteenth Tho. Walsing.
of November, on which day the King was borne, having now accomplished the 50.
year of his age, whereupon, he pardoned such as were guilty of Treason to his
person, releassed prisoners, revoked outlawes, and at the petition of the
commons, he commanded pleas to be used in English, and not in French, as they
had continued since the Conquest. He made Leonell his son, Earl of Hulster,
then being in Ireland, Duke of Clarence: and his son John, Earl of Richmond,
he made Duke of Lancaster: and Edmond his son, he made Earl of Cambridge.

In the said Parliamente was granted to the King for Subsedie of vvoolles.
three years following, six and twenty shillings, eight pence, of every
Sack of wool to be transported beyond the Seas.

mother. Sea. Cro.

John Louekin Fishmonger, the 28. of October.

This John Louekin Stockfishmonger, four times Mayor of London, twice by
election, and twice by the Kings appointment, John Leyland.
for that he was borne in the Town of Kingston Hospital at Kingston upon
Thamis.
upon Thamis, he builded there a Chapel called Magdalenes, ^o the which he
joined an Hospital, wherein was a Master, two Priests, and certain poor
men: and for that the Saint Michael^ Church in Crooked Lane builded.
parish Church of Saint Michaell by Crooked Lane of London, in which Parish he
then dwelled, was a very small and homely thing (standing in part of that
ground, where now of late the Personage house is builded) and the ground
therabout a filthy plot, by reason of the Butchers in Eastcheape, who made the
same their Lest haw, he on the same ground builded the fair new parish Church
of Saint Michaell, now standing, and was there buried in the middle of the
Quire, under a fair Tomb of Stone, with the images of him and his wife graven
in Allablaster upon the same Tomb. He also (as writes John Leyland) founded a
College to the same Church near thereunto adjoining. The said parish Church
of Saint Michaell, has bin since increased Eastwarde, with a new Quier, and
side Chapels, by Sir William Walworth Fishmonger, and Mayor of London (as
shall be showed in the fourth year of King Richard the second.) Also, the
Tomb of John Louekin was removed, and a ^lat stone of gray Marble, garnished
with plates of Latin, and an Epitaph, was laid upon him, as it yet remains.

Third Pestilence. Dearth of Corn. 1369


Simon Mordin Stockfishmonger, the 28. of October.

The third mortality or Pestilence was this year, whereof dyed Blaunch,
Duches of Lancaster, and was buried in Paul's Church at London.

This year was a great dearth of Corn, so that a Bushel of Wheat at London
was sold for two shillings six pence, of Barlie twenty pence, of Otes twelve
pence.

The xv. of August died Queen Philip, wife to Edward the third, and was
buried at Westminster.

Quenesborough, Kingston upon Hull, and Saint Botolphes, alias Bostowne, made
Staples by Parliament.

The Kings son John Duke of Lancaster, and Humfrey Bohan Earl of Hereford,
with a great Army went into France, where they little prevailed, because an
huge Army of Frenchmen had pitched their Tents upon the top of Chalk
hill, near unto Caleis, so strongly, that they could not be set on without
great loss and damage, but shortly after, Thomas Beawchampe, Earl of
Warwike, arrived at Caleis with a number of chosen Soldiers, at whose coming,
the Frenchmenne leaving their tents and victualles, fled away,
nevertheless, he passed forth, spoiling and wasting the Isle of Caws with fire
and sword, but as he returned toward Caleis, he fell sick, whereof he dyed,
and the other Captains returned without honor.

John Piel: Hugh Holditch, the 28. of September. Sherifes. Mayor. Anno reg. 44
The King borovved great sums. 1370


John Chichester Goldsmith, the 28. of October.

King Edward borrowed of the Prelates and other, many great sums of money,
saying, he would bestow the same in defense of the Church and Realm, but about
Midsomer he sent a great army into France, whereof Sir Roberte Knowles was
general, a man, who before time had fortunately handled the beyond sea wars,
so long as they were ruled by his counsel, but toward Winter, the young Lords
said they ought not to be subject to him who was not so noble of birth as
they, and so dividing themselves into diverse companies, Sir Robert Knowles
departed into Briteine to his own Castles which he had conquered. The Lords
being so divided, the Frenchmen set upon them, took prisoners whom they
listed, and slew the residue.

A great part of Gascoigne fell from the Prince, because of the strange
exactions he laid upon them: also sickness increasing upon him, he returned
into England with his wife and his son Richard, and resigning into his
fathers hands the government of Gascoigne.

The Monastery of Abingdon, five miles from Oxforde, was spoiled by them of
Oxford, together with the Artificers Matthew Parker.
of Abingdon.

John Barnes Mercer, the 28. of October.

John, Duke of Lancaster, and Edmond Earl of Cambridge, returning out of
Gascoigne, brought with them two daughters of Peter late King of Spain, whom
afterward they took to be their wives: the Duke married the elder, and from
that time wrote himself King of Castile.

The Englishmen fought a battle on the Sea with the Battle on the Sea.
Flemings, and took five and twenty ships laden with salt.

The Frenchmen beseeged Rochell, to the removing whereof, was sent the Earl of
Penbroke, with a number of men of arms, upon whom fell the Spanish Navy in
the Haven of Rochell, who slew and took the Englishmen, and burnt their Navy.
The Earl and many noble men were carried into Spain, together with the Kings
money. King Edward with a great Navy entered the Seas toward Rochell, to
have rescued the same, but the wind being contrary, with heavy cheer he
returned again, having spente in this preparation (as it was said) nine
hundred thousand pound.

John Piel Mercer, the 28. of October.

John Duke of Lancaster entered France with a strong power, and passed through
the Realm without battle, but in the Deserts and Mountains of Aluerne, for
lack of victualles, many of his army dyed: from thence, he went to Bordeaux,
and brought scantly forty horses back with him: it was commonly talked that
he lost thirty thousand Horses in that unlucky voyage. It was a great
misery ^bo. Walsing.
to see the poor state of the men of war, such as were Knights of great
wealth in their Country, having lost men and Horses, were glad to beg from
door to door, and found no relief, for the Country was destroyed, and not
manured, by reason whereof, such dearth was in that Country, that victualles
could scant be gotten for any money. The Duke yet wintered. The tenth of April
following, a day of battle was appointed betwixt him and the Duke of Aniow
at Toulouse. In the mean time, truce was taken till the twentieth of May next
following, but the King of England knew nothing of it. When the day came, a
great power of armed men for the French appeared, the which the Duke of Aniow
had assembled, but yet that day passed without battle, to the great shame
and reproach of the English, for the Frenchmen said, they were ready in field
the day appointed to look for their coming, that came not at all, wherefore
they spoke many reproachful words against the Englishmen, calling them false
cowards, and ha^^ less. And such was the end of that journey.

John Northwold Mercer of London, was slain at the Black heath, for whose
sake, began great debate among the Crafts of London, at the White Friars in
Fleetestreete, for him, and Sir William of Windsore. Lib. Mayor and vic. Lon.


The Clergy granted to the King tenthes, and the Laytie a fifteenth.

50 Good Parliament.


John Ward Grocer, the 28. of October.

A Parliament, commonly called the good Parliament, was holden at Westminster,
in the which* when a Subsidy was demanded, answer was made by Peter de la
Mare, Proloc^tor of the Parliamente, that the King needed not the substance of
his poor Subjects, if he were well and faithfully governed, which he offered
to prove effectually, and promised that if it were found that the King had
need, his subjects should be ready most gladlye to help him according to
their power.

The Knights required to have the Lord Latimer with 1376
other, removed from about the King, whom they said did give him evil
counsel, which being done, certain Prelates, Earls, and other, were
ordained to govern the King, who then was an old man, but this endured not
long. The commons also requested to have removed out of the Kings house, a
certain proud woman called Alice Perce, who by overmuch familiarity that she
had with the King, was cause of much mischief in the Realm, she exceeding
the manner of Women, sat by the Kings Justices, and sometimes by the Doctors
in the Consistories, persuading and dissuading in defense of matters, and
requesting things contrary to law and honesty, to the great dishonor of the
King.

Also Richard Lious and Adam of Bury, Citizens of London, Adam Bury late Mayor.
Richard Lions late Sheriff, a Goldsmith.
were accused by the commo^s, of diverse frauds and deceipts, which they had
done to the King: Richard Lions for money did wisely compou^d and escaped, the
other conuayde himself into Flanders, but Sir Peter de la Mere, who told the
troth, was at the instance of Alice Pierce condemned to perpetual prison at
Notingham.

The eight day of June, Prince Edward departed out of Black Prince deceassed.
Adam Meri^o.
this life, who was in his time the flower of Chivalry: he was buried at
Canterbury, and then King Edward created Richard son of Prince Edward, Earl
of Chester, Duke of Cornwall, and Prince of Wales, and because the King waxed
feeble and sickly, he betook the rule of the land to John of Gaunt Duke of
Lancaster.

The Earl of Warwickes men made a great spoil of the Euisham spoiled.
Abbey of Euisham, and the tenementes thereto belonging, beating and sleying
many of the Abbots men, but by the King an agreement was made betwixt them, but
no full satisfaction.
