William Hulin Fishmonger, the 28. of October.

In this month of October, Henry the young duke of Somerset, Henry Lord Roos,
and Lord Audley, with men of Arms sailed toward Calleis, to the intent the
Duke should have been Captain there: but when he came to land, they Duke of
Somerset fled to Gvvynes. The Lord Audley taken into Calleis. The lord Roos
fled into Flaunders.
of Calleis would have taken him, so that he hardly escaped to the Castle of
Gwines: his soldiers were stripped out of their harness and let go. The Lord
Audley was taken into Calleis, and the Lord Roos fled into Flaunders, and after
returned into England.

Not long after, Richard Lord Rivers was sent to Sa^dwich to keep the town
and certain great ships which lay there at Anchor, but when the Earl of
Warwike saw time convenient, The Lord Rivers and the Lord VVoodvile by force
carried from Sandvvicke.
he sent some of his men to Sandwich by night, ye which took the Lord Rivers
and Antonie Wooduile his son in their beds, and led them over to Calleis,
with all the great ships save one called Grace de Dieu, the which might not be
had away because she was broke in the bottom. Sir Baudwyne Fulford, undertook
on pain of loosing his head, yt he would 1460 Sir Baudvvin Fulford his
enterprise.
destroy yt Earl of Warwike, but when he had spent ye King a thousand marks
in money, he returned again. Then was the Duke of Excester Admiral sent to
the sea with a great The Duke of Excester sent to the Seas.
Navy for to distress the Earl of Warwike and his Navy, he sailing from
Sandwiche to Dertmouth, for lack of victuals and money his Soldiers forsook
him there. And between Sandwiche and Dertmouth he met the Earl of Warwike
coming out of Ireland that had bin there for to speak with the Duke of York,
and brought with him his mother that was sled thither for dread, and led her to
Calleis: but the Duke of Excester durst not set upon the Earl of Warwike, nor
the Earl would not distress him, because he was Admiral and of the Kings
blood, but let him pass by.

In ye month of June. 500. men were sent to conduct the duke of Somerset from
Gwynes into England, but abiding ye wind in ye port of Sandwich, ye Earl of
Warwikes men spoiled them of their harnes, killed their captain Mou^ford and
many other. The Earls at Calleis, sent to the Archbishop of Caunterburie,
Captain Mount sort slain.
and at large to the commons of England certain Articles in writing, beginning
thus: Worshipful sirs, we the Duke of Articles sent from the Duke of York, and
the Barles, to the Archbishop of Caunterburie and to the commons.
York, the Earls of March, Warwike, and Salisburie, sewed and offered to have
come unto the King our Sovereign Lords most noble presence, to have declared
there asore him for our duty to God and to his highness and to the
prosperity and welfare of his noble estate, and to the Common Weal of all his
Land as true liege men, the matters following, that is to say.

In primis the great oppression, extortion, robbery, murder and other
violences done to Gods Church and to his ministers thereof, against Gods and
man's law.

2 Item, the poverty and misery that to our great heaviness our Sovereign
Lord stands in, not having any liuelode of the Crown of England whereof he
may keep his honorable household, which causes the spoiling of his said
liege men by the takers of his said household, which lyuelode is in their
hands that have been destroyers of his said estate, and of the said common
Weal.

3 Item, how his Laws be partially and unrightfully guided, and that by them
that should most love and tender his said Laws, the said oppression and
extortion is most favored and supported, and generally, that al righteousness
and Justice is exiled out of the said land, and that no man dreadeth to offend
against the said Laws.

4 Item, that it will please his said good Grace to live upon his own
liuelode, whereupon his noble Progenitors have in days heretofore lived as
honorably and as worthily as any Christian Princes, and not to suffer the
destroyers of the said land, and of his true subjects, to live thereupon, and
therefore to lack the sustenances that should be belonging to his said estate,
and find his said household upon his poor commons, without payment, which
neither accords with Gods nor man's law.

5 Item, how often the said commons have been greatly and maruellously charged
with taxes and tallages to their great empouerishing, whereof little good has
either grown to the king or to the said land, and of the most substance
thereof the King has left to his part not half so much, and other Lords and
persons, enemies to the said common Weal, have to their own use, suffering
all the old possessions that the King had in France and Normandy, Aniow and
Maine, Gascoyn and Gwiene, won and gotten by his father of most noble memory,
and other his noble progenitors, to be shamefully lost or sold.

6 Item, how they can not cease therewith, but now begin a new charge of
imposition and tallages upon the said people, which never before was seen, that
is to say, every town, ship to find men for ye Kings Guard, taking ensample
thereof, of our enemies and adversaries of France, which imposition and
tallage, if it be continued to heir, heirs, and successors, will be the
heauiest charge and worst ensample that ever grew in England, and the
foresaid subjects, and the said heirs and successors, in such bondage as
their auncetors were never charged with.

7. Item, where the King has now no more liuelode out of his Realm of
England, but only the Land of Ireland, and the town of Calleis, and that no
King Christened has such a Land and a Town without his Realm, diverse Lords
have caused his highness to write letters under his Privy Seal, unto his
Irishe enemies, which never King of England did here to fore, whereby they may
have comfort to enter into the conquest of the said Land, which letters the
same Irishe enemies sent unto me the said Duke of York, and marvelled greatly
that any such letters should be to them sent, speaking therein great shame and
villainy of the said Realm.

8 Item, in like wise the King by excitation and labor of the same Lords,
wrote other letters to his enemies and adversaries in other lands, that in no
wise they should show any favor or good will to the town of Calleis, whereby
they had comfort enough to proceed to the wynning thereof. Considered also,
that it is ordained by the labor of the said Lords, that no where victual nor
other thing of refreshing or defense should come out of England, to the
succor or relief of the said town, to the intent that they would have it
lost, as it may openly appear.

9 Item, it is deemed and ought greatly to be deemed, that after that the same
Lords would put the same rule of England, if they might have their purpose and
intent, into the hands and governance of the said enemies.

10 Item, how continually sith the piteous, shameful, and sorrowful murder
to all England, of that Noble, worthy, and Christian Prince Humfrey Duke of
Gloucester the Kings true uncle, at Bury, it has been labored, studied, and
conspired, to have destroyed and murdered the said Duke of York, and the
issue that it pleased God to send me of the Royal blood, and also of us the
said Earls of Warwike and Salisburie, for none other cause but for the true
heart that God knows we ever have born, and bear to the profit of the Kings
estate, to the Common Weal of the same Realm, and defense thereof.

11. Item, how the Earls of Shrewsburie and Wilshire, and the Lord Beaumount,
our mortal and extreme enemies now and of long time past, having the guiding
about the most Noble person of our said Sovereign Lord, whose highness
they have restrained and kept from the liberty and freedom that belongs to
his said estate, and the supporters and favorers of all the premysses, would
not suffer the Kings said good grace to receive and accept us, as he would
have done if he might have had his own will, into his said presence, dreading
the charge that would have been laid upon them, of the misery, destruction,
and wretchedness of the said Realm, whereof they becauses and not the King,
which is himself as noble, as virtuous, as rightuous and blessed of
disposition, as any Prince earthly.

12. Item, the Earls of Wilshire and Shrewsburie, and the Lord Beaumount, not
satysfyed nor content with the Kings possessions and his goods, stirred and
excited his said highness to hold his Parliament at Couentrie, where an Act
is made by their provocation and labor, against us the said Duke of York, my
sons March and Rutlande, and the Earls of Warwike and Salisburie, and the
Sons of the said Earl of Salisburie, and many other Knights and Esquiers,
of diverse matters falsely and untruly imagined, as they will answer before
almighty God in the day of Dome, the which the said Earls of Salisburie and
Wilshire, and the Lord Beaumount provoked to be made, to the intent of our
destruction and of our issue, and that they might have our lyuelode and goods,
as they have openly robbed and dispoyled all our places and our tenementes, and
many other true men, and now proceed to hangyng and drawing of men by
tyranny, and will therein show the largeness of their violence and malice as
vengeably as they can, if no remedy be provided at the Kings highness, whose
blessedness is neither assenting nor knowing thereof.

We therefore seeing all the said mischiefs, hearing also that the French
King makes in his land great assembly of his people, which is greatly to be
dread for many causes, purpose yet again with Gods grace to offer us to come
again to the said presence of our said Soueraygne Lord, to open and declare
there unto him the mischiefs above declared, and in the name of the land to
sue, in as reverent and lowely wise as we can, to his said good Grace, to
have pity and compassion upon his said true subjects, and not to suffer
the same mischiefs to raygne upon them. Requiring you in Gods behalf, and
praying you in our own, therein to assist us, doing always the duty of liege
men in our persons to our said Sovereign Lord, to his estate, prerogative, and
pre-eminence, and to the suertie of his most Noble person, whereunto we have
ever been and will be as true as any of his subjects alive, whereof we call
God, our Lady S. Marie, and all the Saints in heaven unto witness and record.

In the mean time the Earl of Wilshire treasurer of England, The Earl of
VVilshire and other spoiled Nevvbery.

The Earl of VVilshire stale over the Seas.

to the foresaid Earls, beseeching them in all haste possible to come to

of those people, they prepared to come into this land, against whose coming,
a long Ballet was fixed upon the gates of Canterbury, made in favor of the
Duke of York and the said Earls, beginning thus: In the day of fast and
spiritual affliction, The celestial influence of bodies transitory, etc The
Earls of March, Warwick, and Salisburie, arrived at Sandwich, where met with
them Thomas Bourcher, Archebyshop of Canterbury, The Earl entered into London.
who with his cross borne before him, and a great number of other people,
accompanied them to London, into the which City they entered on the second of
Julye: with them came the Popes legate, to treat of peace if need were. Th^n
was a convocation of the Clergy holden in S. Paul's Church* where the said
Earls being present, the Earl of Warwick recited the cause of their coming
into the land, with the misgouernements thereof, and then made open oath upon
the cross of Canterbury, that they had ever borne true faith and alegiaunce
to King Henry. Then the Earls of March and Warwick, with the Lords
Fauconbridge, Clinton, Borser Priour of Saint John's, Audley, Burgavennie, Say,
and Scrope, the Archbishop, the Popes legate, the Bishops of Excester, Ely,
Salisburie, and Rochester, addressed the^ forth to the King at Northampton,
leaving the Earl of Salisbury to be governor of the City in their absence.
The Lord Scales and Hungerforde, that before the coming of the Earls, were
in the City of London, and would have had the governance thereof, went to the
Tower of London, and with them the Lords Vessy, Louel, Delaware, Kendale a
Gascoigne: Knights, sir Edmond Hampden, Thomas Brune Sheriff of Kent, John
Bruyn of Kent, Geruayes Clyfton treasurer of the King house, Thomas Tyrel, the
Duchess of Excestex, and many other. Then was the Tower of London besieged
both by water and land, that no victualles might come to them. And they that
were within the Tower cast wild fire into the City, and shot many small
Gunnes, whereby they brent and slew me^, women, and children, in the streets:
also they of the City laid great Gunnes on the furtherside of the Thamis
against the Tower, and brake the Walls in diverse places. The King lying in the
Friars at Northa^pton, ordained a strong and myghtie field in the Meddowes
beside the Nunrie, having the river at his back. The Earls with their power
coming to Northampton, sent certain Bishops to the King, beseeching him to
admit y^ Earl of Warwick to come to his presence, to declare their innocence,
which request being denied by the Duke of Buckingham, the Earls sent an
Heralde of Arms, desiring to have hostages for his safe coming and going, but
he might not be heard. The third time the Earl of Warwick sent word to the
King, that at two hours after noone he would speak with him, or dye in y^
field. The Bishop of Hereford, a white Friar the kings Confessor, encouraged
the kings part to fight, wherefore after the battle he was committed to the
Castelf of Warwick, where he was long prisoner. The tenth of July at two of y^
clock after noo^re, y^ Earls of March and Warwick let cry through the field
y^ no man should lay hand upon the King ^e on y^ common people, but on the
Lords, Knights and Espuiers: then both hosts incountred and fought half an
hour, the Lord Gray that was the Kings vaward break the field and came to
the Earls party, and was a great help to them in obtaining the victory:
many on the kings side were flayn, and many y^ fled were drowned in ye river,
y^ Duke of Buckingham, the Earl of Shrowesburie, ye Lord Beaumont and the Lord
Egremont were slain by y^ Kings ^e^t, with many Knights and Esquires: ye kings
ordinance of Guns might not be shot, there was so great rain that day: When
the field was done, and the Earls had the victory, they came to the King, he
being in his tent, and said in this wise. Most noble prince, displease you not
though it have pleased God of his grace to grant us the victory of our mortal
enemies, y^ which by their venomous malice have vntxuely stirred and moved your
highness to exile us out of your land, and would have us put to final shame
and confusion: we come not to y^ intent for to unquiet ne grieve your said
highness, but for to please your noble person, desiring tenderly the high
welfare and prosperity thereof, and of al your realm, and to be your true
liegemen while our lives shall endure. The King of these words was greatly
recomforted, and anon was led to Northampton with procession, where he rested
three days, and came to London the sixteenth of July, and was lodged in the
Bishops Pallaice.

The ninteenth of Julye they that were in the Tower of London, for lack of
victualles yielded and came forth, of the which afterward some were drawn and
headed.

The Lord Scales late in an evening entered a Wherry with three persons, and
rowing toward Westminster, there to have taken Sanctuary, was descried by a
woman, and anon the Wherry men fell on him, killed him, and cast him a land
beside Saint Marie Oueries.

When Queen Margaret heard that the king was taken, she with her son, and
eight persons fled, to the Castle of Hardlagh in Wales, and was robbed by the
way in Lancashire, of all her goods to the valewe of ten thousand marks:
from thence she went into Scotland.

The tenth of August James King of Scotts besieging the Castle of
Rockesborough, was slain with a Gun that brake in his Camp.

The one and twentieth of September the Duke of Somerset came from Gwines into
England. Anno. reg. 39 Sherifes. Mayor.


Richard Flemming: John Lambert, the 28. of September.

Richard Lee Grocer, the. 28 of October.

The vitj. of October a Parliament was begun at Westminster, unto the which
came Ri. duke of York, that a little before Parliament.
was come out of Irelande, and being lodged in the Pallaice, the King being
there, he brake up the doors of the Kings Chamber, so that the King giving him
place, took an other Chamber. Then the said Duke, as right heir by lyneall
descent from Richard the second, challenged the realm, purposing to have bin
crowned on Alhallown day next following, and herevppon sent to the Parliament
in writing his said claim, title, and pedigree. The which claim after
diligent deliberation had and approved, by the said Parliamente, peace and
concord between the king and Duke on the Uigil of Alhalow was established and
concluded, as in Articles follows.

BLessed be John in whose hands and bounty refieth The Articles betwixt King
Henry and the Duke of York
and is the peace and unity betwixt Princes and the Weal of every Realm: I
know by whose direction agreed it is appointed and accorded as follows,
betwixt the most high and most mightis Prince King Henry the sixth King of
England and of France, and Lord of Irelande, on y^ one party, and the right
high and mighty Prince Richard Pla^tagenet Duke of York on that other party,
upon certain matters of variaunce moved betwixt them, and especially upon the
claim and title unto the Crowns of England and of France, and Royal power,
estate and dignity appertayning to the same, and Lordship of Irelande, opened,
showed, and declared, by the said Duke, before all the Lords spiritual and
Temporal, being in this present Parliament.

First where the said Richard Duke of York has declared and opened, as
above is said, title and claim in manner as follows:

That the right noble and worthy Prince, Henry King of England the third, had
issue and lawfullye got Edward his first begotten son, borne at Westminster
the xv. Kalendes of July, in the year of our Lord 12^9. and Edmond his second
son, which was borne on Saint Marcels day, the year 1200. the which Edward
after the death of King Henry his Father, entitled and called King Edward
the first, had issue, Edward his first begotten son, called after the
decease of his Father, King Edward the second, the which had issue, Edward
the third: which Edward the third had issue, Edward Prince of Wales* William
of Hatfield his second son: Leonel the third, Duke of Clarence: John of
Gaun^ fourth, Duke of Lancaster: Edmond of Langley fifth, Duke of York: Thomas
of Woodstocke the sixth, Duke of Gloucester: and W. of Windsor the seventh. The
said Edward Prince of Wales, which dyed in the life time of his Father, had
issue Richard, which succeeded Edward the third his grandsire: Richard dyed
without issue: William of Hatfield the second son of Edward the third, dyed
without issue: Leonel the third son of Edward the third, Duke of Clarence,
had issue Phillip his daughter and heir, which was coupled in matrimony unto
Edmond Mortimer Earl of March, and had issue Roger Mortimer Earl of March
her Son and heir, which Roger had issue of Edmond earl of March, Roger
Mortimer, Anne, and Elianor: which Edmonde, Roger and Alianor dyed without
issue. And the said Anne coupeled in matrimony to Richard Earl of Cambridge,
the son of Edmond of Langley, the fifth son of Henry the third, and had
issue Richard Plantagenet, commonly called Duke of York: John of Gaunt, the
fourth son of Edward, and the younger brother of the said Leonel, had issue
Henry Earl of Darby, which incontinent, after that King Richard resigned the
Crowns of the Realms and Lordship of Irelande, unrighteously entered upon the
same, then being alive Edmonde Mortimer Earl of March, son to Roger
Mortimer Earl of March, son and heir of the said Phillippe, daughter and
heir of the said Leonel, the third son of the said King Edward the
third, to the which Edmonde the right and title of the said Crowns and
Lordship by law and custom belonged. To the which Richard Duke of York, as
son to Anne daughter to Roger Mortimer, Earl of March, son and heir of
the said Phillip, daughter and heir of the said Leonell, the third son of
King Edward the third, the right, title, dignity Royal, and estate of the
Crowns of the Realms of England and France, and the Lordshippe of Irelande,
pertayneth and belongs a fore any issue of the said John of Gaunt, the
fourth son of the same King Edward. The said title notwithstanding and
without prejudice of the said Richard Duke of York, tenderly desiring the
wealth, rest, and prosperity of this land, and to set apart all that might be
trouble to the same, and consyderyng the possession of the said King Hen the
sixth, and that he has for his time been named, taken, and reputed for King
of England and of France, and LORD of Irelande, is contented, agreede, and
consents, that he be had, reputed, and taken for King of England and
France, with the Royal estate, dignitye, and pre-eminence belonging
thereunto, and Lord of, Irelande during his natural life. And for that time,
the said Duke without hurt or prejudice of his said right and title, shall
take, worship, and honor him, for his sovereign Lord.

Item, the said Richard Duke of York, shall promis and bind him by his
solemn oath, in manner and form as follows

In the name of God Amen: I Richard, Duke of York, The oath of Richard Duke
of York.
promise and swear by the faith and truth that I owe to Almighty God, that I
shall never consent, procure, or stir, directly or indirectly, in privy or
aperte, neither, (as much as in me is) shall suffer to be done, consented,
procured, or stirred, any thing that may sound to the abridgement of the
natural life of King Henry the sixth, or to y^ hurt or diminishing of his
reign or dignity royal, by violence or any otherwise, against his freedom
or liberty: but if any person or persons would do or presume any thing to y^
contrary, I shall with all my might and power withstand it, and make it to be
withstoode, as far as my power will stretche there^herevnto, so help me GOD
and his holy Evangelists.

Item, Edward Earl of March, and Edmund Earl of Rutlande, sons of the said
Duke of York, shall make like oath.

Item, it is accorded, appointed, and agreed, that the said Richard Duke of
York, shall be called and reputed from hence forth very and rightful heir to
the crowns, royal estate, dignity and Lordshippe above said, and after the
decease of the said King Henry, or when he will lay from him the said
crowns, estate, dignity, and Lordshippe, the said Duke and his heirs shall
immediately succeed to the said crowns, royal estate, dignity and Lordship.

Item, the said Richard Duke of York, shall have by authority of this
present Parliament, castles, manors, lands and tenementes, with the wards,
marriages, reliefs, services, fines, amercementes, offices, anowsions, fees,
and other appurtenaunces to them belonging, what soever they be, to the yearly
valewe of ten thousand marks over al charges and reprises, where of five
thousand marks shall be to his own state, three thousand five hundred marks
to Edward his first begotten son Earl of March for his estate, and one
thousand pound to Edmond Earl of Rutland his second son, for his yearly
sustentation, in such considerations and such intent as shall be declared by
the Lords of the Kings Counsel.

Item if any person or persons imagine or compass the death of the said Duke,
and thereof probably be attaynte, of open deed done by folks of other
condition, that it be deemed and adjudged high treason.

Item, for the more establishing of the said accord, it is appointed and
consented, that the Lords spiritual and Temporal, being in this present
Parliament, shall make oaths to accept, take, worship, and repute the said
Richard Duke of York, and his heirs, as above is rehearsed, and keep and
observe, and strength in as much as apperteyneth unto them, all the things
abouesayd, and resist to their power, all them that would presume the
contrary, according to their estates and degrees.

Item, the said Richard Duke of York, Earls of March and Rutland, shall
permit and make other to help, aid, and defend the said Lords, and every
of them, against althose that will quarrel, or any thing attempt against the
said Lords or any of them, by occasion of agreemente or consenting to the
said accord, or assistaunce giving to the Duke and Earls or any of them.

Item, it is agreed and appointed, that this accord, and every Article
thereof, be opened and notifyed by the kings letters patents, or otherwise, at
such times and places, and in manner as it shall be thought expedient to the
said Richard Duke of York, with the advice of the Lords of the Kings
Counsel. The King understands certainly, the said title of the said
Richard Duke of York, just, lawful, and sufficient, by the advice and assent
of the Lords, spiritual and Temporal, and the Commons in this Parliament
assembled, and by authority of y^ same Parliament declares, approves,
ratifyeth, confirms and accepts the said title, just, good, lawful, and
true, and thereunto gives his assent and agreemente of his free will and
liberty. And over that, by the said advice and authority declares,
entitleth, calls, stablisheth, affirms, and reputeth the said Richard
Duke of York, very true and rightful heir to the Corones, Royal estate, and
dignity of y^ realms of England and of France, and of the Lordship of
Irelande aforesaid, and that according to y^ worship and reverence that thereto
belongs, he be taken, accepted and reputed, in worship and reverence, by all
the states of the said Realm of England, and of all his subjects thereof,
fauyng and ordayning by the same authority, the King to have y^ said
Corones, Realm, royal estate, dignity, and pre-eminence ofthe same, and the
said Lordshippe of Ireland during his life natural. And furthermore by the
same advice and authority will, consents and agrees, that after his
decease, or when it shall please his highness to lay from him the said
Corones, estate, dignity, and Lordshippe, the said Richard Duke of York and
his heirs, shall immediatelye succeed him in the said Corones, Royal estate,
dignitye, and worship, and them then have and inioye, any act of Parliament,
statute, or ordinance, or other thing to the contrary made, or interruption,
or discontinuaunce of possession notwithstanding. And moreover, by the said
advise and authority, stablisheth, grants, confirms, approves,
ratifieth, and accepts the said accord, and al things therein contained, and
thereunto freely and absolutely assenteth agrees, and by the same advice and
authority ordayneth and establishes, that if any person or persons ymagine
or compass the death of the said Duke, and probably be attaynt of open deed
done by folks of that conditions, that it be deemed and adjudged high
Treason. And furthermore ordayneth and establishes by the said advice and
authority, that all statutes, ordinances and acts of Parliament, made in
the time of the said King He^rie the fourth, by the which he and the heirs of
his body coming of Henry late King of England the fifth, the son and heir
of the said King Henry the fourth, and the heirs of King Henry the fifth,
were or be inheritable to the said Crowns and Realms, or to the heritage of
the same, be adnulled, repelled, dampened, cancelled, void, and of none effect.

And over this, the King by the said advice, assent and authority, ordayneth
and establishes, that all other acts and statutes made before this time by
act of Parliamente, not repelled or adnulled by like authority, or otherwise
void, be in such force, effect, and virtue, as they were before the making of
these ordinances, and that no letters pattents royalx of record, nor acts
Judicial, made or done before this time not repelled reuersed, ne otherwise
void by law, be prejudiced or hurt by this present act. Also it was
ordained by the same Parliamente, that the said Richard Duke of York,
should be called Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornwall, and Earl of Chester, and
protector of England.

In the month of December, the Duke of Somerset and the Earl of Devonshire,
went into the North Country with eighte hundred men, and anon after, the
said Duke of York, the Earl of Rutlande his son, and the Earls of
Salisburie a little before Christmasse with a few persons went into the
North also for to repress the malice of the Northern men, the which loved
not the Duke of York, ne the Earl of Salisburie, and were lodged at the
Castle of Sandale, and at Wakefielde. Then the Lord Neuill, brother to the
Earl of Westmerlande, under a color of Friendship, came to the Duke of
York, requyring of him a commission for him to raise the people for to
chastise the Rebels as he said, but when he had raised to the number of
eighte thousand men, he brought them to the Lords of that Country, that
is to say, the Earl of Northumberlande, Lord Clifforde, and the Duke of
Somerset, that were adversaries to the Duke of York, and on the last of
December they fell on the said Duke Richard, killed him and his Son the
Earl of Rutland, and many other knights and Esquiers, to wit the Lord
Harington, Thomas Harington Knighte, Sir Thomas Neuil son to the Earl of
Salisburie, and Sir Henry Ratforde Knight, and other, to the number of 2200.
The Earl of Salisburie was taken alive and led by the Duke of Somerset to
the Castle of Pomfraite, and had grant of his life for a great sum of
money, but the common people of the Country which loved him not, took him out
of the Castle by violence, and smote off his head. When the death of these
Lords was known ^^ the King, he commanded writs and commissions to be sent
into the shires to the people, and to go against the Rebels into the North
to suppress them, but they of the North came sodainelye down to the Town of
Dunstaple, robbing all the Country and people as they came, spoiling Abbayes,
Priories, and Parish Churches, bearing away Chalisses, books, ornaments and
other, whatsoever was worth the carriage, as though they had bin Sarisens and
no Christians, against whom, the twelfth of February, the Duke of Norffolke
and Suffolk, the Earls of Warwick and Arundale, the Lord Bonuile and other,
with the King, went out of London toward Saint Albons; and when they heard
that they of the North were so nyghe, they took a field beside a little
Town called Sandriage not far from Saint Albons, on Barnarde Heathe, in a
place called No man's Land, where the King stood and saw his men slain on
both sides, till at the last through the wythdrawyng many of the Kentishmen
with their Captain Louelace that was the vaward, King Henry's part lost the
field, the Lords fled, and the King went to Queen Margaret that was come with
the Northern men and her son Edward. The Earl of Warwick went toward
the Earl of March that was coming toward London out of Wales. The Lord
Bonuile would have withdrawn him, but the King assured him to have no bodylye
harm: nevertheless at the instance of the Queen, the Duke of Excester, and
the Earl of Devonshire, he was beheaded at Saint Albons, and with him Sir
Thomas Kyriell of Kente. This battle was fought on Shroue Twesday the
seventeenth of February, Exlibre Norwicensis.
in the which was slain. 1916 persons. The same day Thomas Thorpe Baron of the
Exchequer was beheaded at High Gate by the commons of Kent. Then the Citizens
of London dreading the malice of the Queen and the Duke of Somerset, sent
unto them the Duchess of Buckingham with other, to treat for to be
beneuolent to the City, for the which a sum of money was promised, and that
they should come to the City with a certain number of persons, where upon
certain spears and men of arms were sent to have entered the City before
the Dukes coming, whereof some were slain, some sore hurt, and the remnaunte
put to flighte by the Commons, who took the Keys of the gates, and manfully
defended the City until the coming of Edward Earl of March,
where-throughe King Henry with Queen Margaret and the Northern men were
forced to return again Northwarde.

The third of February, Edward Earl of March fought with the Welchmen
beside Wigmore in Wales, near unto Mortimers Cross, whose Captains were the
Earl of Penbroke, and the Earl of Wilshire, where he put them to flight, and
slew of the Welchemen about four thousand. Owen Tewther (whom John
Leylande says should be called Me^^dicke,) Father to the said Earl
Penbroke, which Owen had married Katherin mother to King Henry the sixth,
was there taken and beheaded, and afterward buried in the a Chapel of the Gray
Friars Church in Hereforde: the day before this battle, about ten of the
clock before noone, were seen three Suns in the firmament, shyning a like
clear, which after closed together all in one.

The eight and twentieth of February, Edward Earl of March, accompanied with
the Earl of Warwick, and a mighty power of Marchmen, came up to London, where
he was joyfully received, and on the second day of March being Sunday, all his
host was mustered in Saint John's field, where was read among the people
certain Articles and points that King Henry had offended in, and then it was
demanded of them whether the said Henry were worthy to reign still, and the
people cried nay, nay. Then was it asked if they would have the Earl of March
to be their King, and they said yea, yea: then certain Captains were sent
to Earl of March elected King.
the Earl of March, at Baynardes Castle, and told the Earl that the people
had chosen him King, whereof he thanked God and them, and by the advice of the
Archbyshoppe of Canterbury, the Bishop of Excester, and the Earl of
Warwick with other, he took it upon him. The Duchess of York, mother to
Edward Earl of March, fearing the fortune of the world, sent her two
younger sons George and Richard over the seas, to the City of Vtricke in
Almaine, where they remained till their elder brother had got the Crown. Also
Phillip Malpas Alderman of London, Thomas Citizens of London fled.
Vaghan Esquire, Master William Atclife, with many other, fearing the Queens
coming to London, shypped them in a ship of Antwerpe, purposing to have
sailed thither: but by the way they were taken by a French ship named the
Colmapne, and at length delivered for great ransom.

Edward Earl of March, being elected as is abouesaid, Edward Earl of March
took on him the kingdom.
on the next morrow went in procession at Paul's, and offered there, and after
Te Deum being sung, he was with great royalty conveyed to Westminster, and
there in the Hall set in the kings seat with Saint Edwards Scepter in his
hand, and then asked of the people if they would have him King, and they cried
yea, yea. Then after certain homages by him received, he was with Procession
conuayed into the Abbay there, and set in the Quire as King, while Te Deum
was singing: that done, he offered at Saint Edwardes Shryne, and then returned
by water unto Saint Paul's and was there lodged within the Bishops Pallaice.
Thus took he possession of the Realm, upon a Tuisday being the fourth of
March, and was proclaimed King of England, by the name of Edward the fourth
when King Henry had reigned thirty years, eight months and odd days.

Edward Earl of March.


Edward Earl of March borne at Roane, son and heir to Anno. reg. 1 10.
Rouse.
Richard Duke of York, about the age of eighteen years, began his reign
the fourth day of March, by the name of Edward the fourth, in the year. 1460.
he was a man of noble courage and great wit: but in his time was much trouble
and unquietness in the realm.

The twelfth of March, Walter Walker a Grocer that Walter Walker beheaded.
dwelt in Cheap, for words spoken touching King Edward, was beheaded in
Smithfield. This Grocer is he, whom Master Hal mistaketh to be Burdet, of whom
ye shall find in the xvij. year of this King.

The same xij. day of March in the afternoon: King Edward with great triumph
rode through the City of London 1461
to Bishops Gate, and so took his journey toward the North, where between
Shirburne in Elmet, and Todcaster, all the North party met him, and on
Palm Sunday the. xxix. of March fought a great battle between Towton and
Saxton, in which were slain, Henry Percy Earl of Northumberlande, John Lord
Clifforde, John Lord Neuil, Leo Lord Wells, Ranulph Lord Dacre, and many
other on both parties, to the number of five and thirty thousand seven
hundred and eleauen persons, but King Edward gatte the field. Many of the
Bones of these men were buried John Leyland.
in the Churchyard of Saxton: they were first buried in five pittes half a
mile off by North in Saxton field, yet appearing. Towton village is a mile
from Saxton, where a great Chapel was begone by Richard the third, but not
finished, in which Chapel were buried also many of the men flaine at
Palmsonday field. This field was as much in Saxton Parish, as in Towton,
yet it bare the name of Towton.

The Duke of Excester, the Duke of Somerset, the Lord Roos, the Hungerford and
many other, fled to York to king Henry, and then they with the King, Queen,
and Prince, King Henry fled into Scotland.
fled toward Scotland to Barwicke, and so to Edenborough.

King Edward went to York, and then to Durham, and when he had quieted the
Country, returned Southwarde. Thomas Courtney Earl of Devonshire, was taken
and beheaded in York Castle, James Butler Earl of Wilshire was beheaded at
Newcastell, the Lord Fitz Walter was drowned at Ferybridge.

The town of Barwicke was delivered to the Scots by king Henry the sixth on
Saint Marks day.

The. xxvj. of June the Mayor of London with the Aldermen in Scarlet, and the
Commons in green, brought King Edward from Lambeth to the Tower of London,
where he made eight and twenty Knights, and on the morrow he dubbed four
mo, and on the eight and twentieth of June he was crowned at Westminster with
great solempnitie of Bishops and other temporal Lords.

And on the morrow after the King was crowned again in Westminster Abbay in the
worship of God and Saint Peter and on the next morrow he went Crowned in Paul's
Church of London, in the honor of God and Saint Paul, and there an Angel
came down and censed him, at which time was so great a multitude of people in
Paul's, as ever was seen in any days. And soon after his Coronation, the
King made his States created.
brother George Plantagenet Duke of Clarence and his other brother Richard,
duke of Gloucester: William Stafford Esquier, Lord Stafford of Southwike: sir
William Hebert, Lord Herbert, and after Earl of Penbroke: and the said Lord
Stafford Earl of Devonshire. After this he made Edward Lord Gray of Ruthen
Earl of Kent: Henry Lord Bourcher Earl of Essex: John Lord of Buckingham,
Lord of Mountioy: sir John Heyward, Lord Heyward* William Hastings, Lord
Hastings, and after that great Chamberlain: Richard Woodvile Lord Rivers:

of in Cheap.
the Coronation of King Edward, one John Dauy had his hand stricken off, at the

Hughe Wiche Mercer, the 28. of October.

The. iiij. of November began a Parliament at Westminster, wherein King Henry,
his Queen, and his son, were disherited of the Crown: Henry Duke of
Excester, Henry Duke of Somerset, Thomas Earl of Devonshire, etc. to the
number of. 140. were attainted and disherited. Shortly the Earl Anno. reg. 2.
of Oxford, and Awbrey his son, sir Thomas Tudenham Knight, William Tirrell,
and John Mongomerie Esquiers, 1462
were detect and at several times beheaded at the Tower hill, and after that
many other.

The. xxvij. of March King Edward went Northwarde so far as Stamforde, where
he was informed that King Henry had procured the Frenchmen and Scots to enter
this land, in resisting whereof King Edward sent his Privy Seal through
England, to move men to give him a certain su^me of money, which they granted
liberally. The Lord Fauconbridge Earl of Kent, was appointed to keep the
Seas, with the Lord Audeley, Lord Clinton, Sir John Heyward, sir Richard
Walgraue, and other, to the number of ten thousand, which landed in Britain,
and wanne the town of Conqnet, with the Isle of Reth, etc. In Michaelmas Term
king Edward sat in the Kings bench three days together in open court, to
understand how his laws were executed.

William Hampton: Barthelmew James, the 28. of Sep. Sherifes. Mayor.


Thomas Coke Draper, the 28. of October.

Queen Margaret wife to Henry the sixth, landed in the North, where having but
small succor and evil fortune, she was feign to take the Sea again, and by
tempest of weather was driven to Barwicke, where she landed, but lost her
ships and goods. In December King Edward laid siege to the Castles of
Bambrugh, Dunstonbrugh, and Alnewike. Henry Bowfort Duke of Somerset, sir
Ralph Percie, and other yielded Bambrugh on Christmas even, and were taken to
the Kings favor. King Edward granted to the Duke of Somerset a. 1000. marks
by the year, where of he was never paid, the Earl of Penbroke, sir Thomas
Fyndern, and other, went into Scotland.

On S. John's day Dunstonburgh was yielded. On y^ Twelfe even Peirs^e Brasile
the great warrior of Normandy came to help the Queen Margaret with
Frenchmen, and. xx. thousand Scots, to remove King Edwardes men from Alnewike
siege, and the residue of other Castles there. By whose coming King Edwardes
men were afearde of the Scotts, as reculing from the siege, and the Scotts
afearde of Edwardes men, least they had reculed to bring them into a trap. And
Henry's me^ issuing out, of too much boldness, gave Edwards me^ opportunity
to enter into the Castle: on the morrow after the Twelfe day, the Earl of
Warwike made xv. knights: Anno reg. 3.
these. iij. Castles were committed* to ye keeping of sir Ralph Gray, and after
again King Henry with his Queen and 1463
their fellowship entered them and kept them.

About Midsomer the Scots with many French and Englishmen, laid siege to the
Castle of Norham, but were forced to leave it as they found it. The Earl of
Warwike wan the town of Barwike, where he made five Bannertes and* xxij.
knights and went into Scotland, where he burnt Lawghmaban, Iedeworth, Galowey,
and many other Towns, and returned to Barwike.

The Minster of York, and the steeple of Christ's Church in Norwiche were
brent.

Matthew Phillip Goldsmith, the 28* of October.

In the month of April, King Edward made great Anno. reg. 4. 1464
preparation against King Henry, and on Saint Marks day Ralph Percie Lord
Hungerforde, with a great power, purposing to have distressed sir John Neuil,
Lord Mountacute, was himself slain, with many other.

The. xv. of May King Henry's power being at Hexham, the Lord Mountacute with
a power came thither, and enclosed them round about. There were taken and
slain many Lords that were with King Henry, but he himself was fled iiij.
days before into Lancashire, where he and other lived in caves full hardly
unknown more than a year. On Trinity Sunday King Edward made the Lord
Mountacute Earl of Northumberland and warden of the Marches. The Earls of
Warwike and Northumberlande took Bambrugh Castle and beheaded sir Ralph Gray,
at Doncaster. The Earl of Warwike was sent into France, to conclude a marriage
with the French Kings sisters daughter for K. Edward, which he did, K. Edward
married.
but in the mean while, on the first of May, King Edward took to wife

Paul, late wife to sir John Gray, slain at Courton field on King Henry's
part, which marriage was kept secret almost half a year.

King Edward took the Chauncellorship from the Bishop of Excester, brother to
the Earl of Warwike, and gave it to the Bishop of Bathe.

A new Coin was made, a Rose Noble at. x. shillings, the half Noble five
shillings, and the farthing two shillings sir pence, an Angelet six shillings
eight pence, ye half thereof three shillings four pence.

xxxix. Knights.

King Henry was taken in Cletherwood, beside Bungerley King Henry taken.
Hyppingstons in Lancashire, by Thomas Talbot son and heir to sir Edward
Talbot of Basshall, and John Talbot his cosyn of Colebry, which deceived him
being at his dynner at Wadington Hall, and brought him toward London, with his
legs bound to the stirops, where he was met by the Earl of W^rwike, and
arested at Esyldon* Doctor Manning Deane of Windsore, Doctor Bedle and young
Ellerton being in his company, with their feet bound under the horse bellyes,
were brought to the Tower of London.

A license was granted to convey certain Coteswold sheep Sheep tra^sported
ouet the seas. Long piked Shone forbid.
into Spain, which have since greatly multiplied there.

It was proclaynied throughout England, that the beakes or pikes of Shoone and
Boots should not pass. ij. inches, upon pain of cursing by the Clergy, and
forfeting. xx. s^. to be paid one Noble to the King, one other to the
Cordewayners of London, and the third to the chamber of London: and for other
Cities and Towns the like order was taken. Before this time and since the
year of our Lord. 1282. the pikes of shoes and boots were of such length,
that they were feign to be tied up to their knees with chains of silver and
guilt, or at the least with silk laces.

Sir Ralph Verney Mercer, the 28. of October.

The. xj. of February Queen Elizabeth was delivered at Westminster of a
Daughter also named Elizabeth; who was long after married to King Henry the
seventh; whose Christening was done in the Abbey with ye most solemynitie that
might be, and the more, because the King was assured by his Physicians, that
the Queen was conceived with a Prince, which proved otherwise as ye have heard.

This year was the Lord Hungerford beheaded at Salisburie. Anno. reg. 6 1466
Also sir Thomas Hungerford Knight, son to the Lord Hungerford, and Henry
Courteney of right Earl of Deuo^shire, were beheaded at Salisburie. The Lord

Thomas Olgraue Skinner, the 28. of October.

The. viij. of May began a Parliament at Westminster, where was granted two
fiftenes and a demi.

The xviij. of June Margaret sister to King Edward the Lady Margaret the Kings
sister married to the Duke of Burgoigne.
fourth began her journey from the Wardrobe in London, toward her marriage we
Charles Duke of Burgoigne: first she offered in the Church of S. Paul, and then
rode through the City, the Earl of Warwike riding before her, with Earls and
Barons a great number, the Duchess of Norfolk, with other Ladies and
Gentlewomen in great number. And at her entry into Cheap, the Mayor of London
and his brethren the Aldermen, presented her with a pair of rich Basins, ^ in
them an. 100. ^. of gold, and that night she lodged at the Abbey of Stratford,
where the King then lay: from thence she took her journey to Canterbury. The
King riding after to see her shipping, on ye first of July, she took ye sea at
Margate, and there took leave of ye King her brother, and departed. There
returned back again with ye King, the Duke of Clarence, the Duke of
Gloucester, ye Earls of Warwike, Shrewsburie, and Northumberland. And there
abode with her in the ship, the Lord Scales, the Lord Dacres her
Chamberlain, sir John Wodvile, sir John Heyward, and many other famous
Knights and Esquiers: she was shipped in the new Ellen of London, and in her
Navy the John of Newcastle, the Marie of Salisburie, and many other Royal
ships, and the morrow landed at Sluice in Flanders, and as soon as her ship
and company of ships were entered into ye Haven, there received her sir Simo^ de
Leleyn and the water Bailie, in diverse Boats and Barks apparelled ready for
her la^ding. The first estate y^ received her was ye Bishop of V^right well
accompanied, and the Countess of Shorn bastard daughter to Duke Phillip of
Burgoygne, and with her many Ladies and Gentlewome^, and so proceeding in at
the gate of the town, the same town was presented to her, she to be
Sovereign Lady thereof: also they gave her. xij. marks of gold Troy weight,
the which was. 200. ^ of English Money, and so she proceeded through the town
to her lodging, every householder standing in the street with a torche in his
hand burning. On the morrow the old Duchess of Burgoygne came to her,
accompanied with many great Estates. On the. iij. of July came the* Duke of
Borgoigne to Sluice with xx. persons secretly, and was there openly affianced to
the Lady Margaret, by the Bishop of Salisburie and the Lord Scales, in
presence of the Lord Dacre, the Duches of Norfolk, the Lady Scales, and all
the Knights, and Esquiers, Gentlewomen enuironing the Chamber.

On the viij. of July being Saturday, by the Duke of Burgoignes appointment,
the Lady Margaret removed by water to the Dame. And on the Sunday in the
morning betwixt v. and. vj. of the clock, the marriage was solemnized betwixt
them, by the Bishops of Salisburie and of Turney, there being present the old
Duches of Burgoigne, the Lord Scales, the Lord Dacre, with the Knights,
Esquiers, Ladies and Gentlewome^ that came out of England, the great triumphs,
feastings, shows of Pageants, with other strange devises, and Justings, were
such as I have not read the like, and would be over long in this place to set
down.

Sir Thomas Cook late Mayor of London, was by one named Robert Fabian. Sir
Thomas Cook.
Hawkins appeached of treason, for the which he was sent to the Tower, and his
place within London seized by the Lord Ryuers, and his wife and servants
clearly put out thereof. The cause was this: The forenamed Hawkins came upon a
season unto the said sir Thomas, requesting him to lend a thousand marks upon
good suertie, whereunto he answered, that first he would know for whom it
should be, and for what intent, at length understanding it should be for the
use of Queen Margaret, he answered he had no current wares whereof any shifts
might be made without too much loss, and therefore required Hawkins to move him
no farther in that matter, for he intended not to deal withal: yet the said
Hawkins exhorted him to remember, what benefits he had received by her when
she was in prosperity, as by making him her Wardrober, and customer of
Hampton, etc. but by no means the said Cook would grant goods nor money,
although at the last the said Hawkins required but an hundredth pound, he was
feign to depart without the value of a penny, and never came again to move
him which so rested two or three years after till the said Hawkins was cast
in the Tower, and at length brought to the brake, called the Duke of Excesters
daughter, by mean of which pain he showed many things, amongst ye which the
motion was one, that he had made to sir Thomas Coke and accused himself so
far that he was put to death: by mean of which confession the said sir
Thomas was troubled as before is showed. After the said sir Thomas had lain in
the Tower from Whitsontide fill about Michaelmas, in the which season many
enquiries were made to find him guilty, and ever quit, till one jury by
means of sir John Fogge, endited him of treason, after which an other
determine was set at the Guildhall, in the which sat with ye Mayor, the Duke of
Clarence, the Earl of Warwike, ye Lord Rivers, sir John Fogge with other of
ye Kings counsel, to the which place the said Thomas was brought and there
arraygned upon life and death, where he was acquitted of ye said indictment, and
had to the Counter in Bredstreete, and from thence to the Kings bench. After a
certain time that he was thus acquitted, his wife gat again the possession of
her house, ye which she found in an evil plight, for such servants of y^ Lord
Rivers and sir John Fogge, as were assigned to keep it, made hauoke of what
they listed. Also at his place in Essex named Guydy hall, were set an other
sort to keep that place, the which destroyed his Dear in his Park, his
Connies and his Fish without reason, and spared not Brass, Pewter, bedding
and all that they might carry, for the which might never one penny be gotten
in recompense, yet could not sir Tho. Cook be delivered til he had paid 8000.
^. to ye* K. and 800. ^. to ye Queen.

In the end of August the Castle of Harlowe was won Harlovv Cas^l^ vvonne.
by the assault of the Lord Herberd, the which Castle was one of the
strongest holds in Wales.

This year many murmurous tales ran in the City, between ye Earl of Warwike,
and the Queens blood, ye which Earl was ever had in great favor of the
Commons of this land, by reason of y^ exceeding household which he daily kept in
all Countries where ever he soiourned or lay, and when Earl of VVarvvike his
house keeping.

acquaintance in that house, he should have had as much soden and roast as he
might carry upon a long Dagger.

Sir John Stockton Mercer, the 28. of October.

Sir John Crosby Knight, one of the late named Sherifes of London for this

and was buried in the Parish Church of Saint Helen in Bishops gate

forty pound: to the* repayring of London Wall one hundred pound: toward the
making of a new Tower of stone at the South end of London bridge, if the same
were begun by the Mayor and commonaltie within. x. years next after his
deceasse, one hundred pound: to the reparations of Rochester bridge. x. pound:
to every the prisoners in and about London liberally. Also he gave to the
Wardens and Commonaltie of the Grocers in London two large pottes of Silver
chaced half guilte, waying. xitj. pound v. ounces of Troy weight, to be
occupied in their common hall, and else where, at their discretions. Queen
Elizabeth wife to Edward the fourth, being in the Sanctuary at Westminster,
Prince Ed. born in the Sa^ctuarie.
was delivered of a Prince on the. iitj. of November, who was after King Edward
the fifth.

King Edward with the Lord Hastings, the Lord Say, ix. hundred Englishmen, and
iij. hundred Flemings, would have landed in Essex, but there the Earl of
Oxfordes brother put them Anno reg. 11
off, and after he landed sore weather beaten at Rauenesporne, within Humber on
Holdernesse, and there rose on him Holdernesse 1471
men, whose Captain was sir John Westerdale a Priest, after cast into the

claim no title of the Crown, but only his Dukedom of York, nor would not
have done before, but at ye exciting of the Earl of Warwike, and cried in every

Marquis Mountacute had 4000 men, and would have fought with King Edward, but
that he had received letters from the Duke of Clarence, that the should not
fight until he came. Whereupon he keeping Lecester still, suffered Edward to
march toward London. A (...) of Clarence with seven thousand(...) Edward,

Posterne, and there took King Henry, and the Archbishop of York, and sent

The Earl of Warwike, the Duke of Excester, the Marquis Barnet field.
Mountacute, and the Earl of Oxford, we many Knights came with their host
toward Barnet: Wherefore King Edward took King Henry with him, and
preoccupied ye town of Barnet all the night: the Earl of Warwike and his
retinue remained on the plain without the town, shooting gu^nes one at the
other. And in ye morning being Easter day and ye xiitj. of April, they fought
in a thick mist from. iitj. of ye clock in the morning till. x. and diverse
times the Earl of Warwikes men supposed that they had got the victory of
the field, but it happened that ye Earl of Oxfords men had a star we
streams both before and behind on their liueries, and King Edwards men had
the sun with streams on their lyuery: whereupon the Earl of Warwikes men by
reason of the mist not well decerning the badges so like, shot at the Earl of
Oxfordes men that were on their own part, and then the Earl of Oxforde and
his men cried treason, and fled with eight hundred men. The Marquis Mountacute
was privily agreed with King Edward, and had gotten on his lyuerie, but one of
his brothers the Earl of Warwikes men espying this fell upon him and killed
him.

The Earl of Warwike seeing all this, lepte on a horse to fly, and coming to
a woodde where was no passage, one of King Edwardes men came to him, killed
him, and spoiled him to the naked skin. Sir William Tirrell Knight was
killed on the Earl of Warwikes ^^rt. The Duke of Excester fought manfully and
was diss^^yled, wounded, and left for dead from seven in the morning till. 4.
of the clock in the afternoon, and then being brought to a servants house
of his there by, called Ruthland, he had a Surgeon, and after was conveyed
into Westminster Sanctuary. The Lord Cromwell son and heir to the Earl of
Essex, the Lord Barnes son and heir, to the Lord Say, were slain on King
Edwardes party, and on both parts to the number of four thousand, which
were buried on the same plain, where after a Chapel was builded.

The morrow after Easter day, were ye bodies of the Earl Job. Rastall.
of Warwike, and the Marquis Mountacute laid naked in Paul's Church in
London, that all men might see them, King Henry with the Archbishop of York,
were sent to the Tower of London.

At this time Queen Margaret, and Prince Edward her son had line on ye sea.
xvtj. days let with foul weather, and on Easter day at even they landed
with their French Battle at Tevvkesburie.
Navy at Weymouth, and so came to Excester, from thence to Tewkesburie, and
pitched his field by Seuerne. Edward the fourth being come from London,
fought with Prince Edward Liber Tewx.
at Tewkesburie, on the fourth of May, took Queen Margaret prisoner with
Prince Edward her son, whom cruelly he smote on the face with his gawntlet,
and after his servants slew him. Edmond Duke of Somerset, and sir Hugh
Courteney fled from Prince Edward and lost him the field. There was slain
Courteney Earl of Devonshire, Lord John of Somerset, Lord Wenlocke, sir
Edmond Flamdene, sir Robert Whittingham, sir William Vaus, sir Nicholas Haruie,
sir John Deluis, sir William Filding, sir Thomas Fizhony, sir John Laukenor.
King Edward entering a Church in Teweksburie with his sword drawn, a Priest
brought the Sacrament against him, and would not let him enter until he had
granted his pardon to these that follow: the Duke of Somerset, the Lord of
Saint John's, sir Humfrey Audeley, sir Geruis of Clifton, sir William Crimeby,
sir William Carry, sir Thomas Tresham, sir William Newbrough Knights, Henry
Tresham, Walter Courteney, John Florie, Jews Miles, Robert Iackson, James
Gower, James Deluis, son and heir to sir John Deluis, all these where they
might have escaped, tarryed in the Church (trusting in the Kings pardon,) from
Saterdaye till Mondaye, when they were taken out and beheaded.

About this time sir Walter Wroitile, and sir Geffrey Thomas the Bastard.
Gates Knights, governors of Caleis, sent sir George Broke Knight from
Caleis with. 300. soldiers to Thomas the Bastard Fauconbridge, Captain of
the Earl of Warwickes Navy, willing him to raise the Country of Kente, and
to go to London, there to take King Henry out of the Tower, and then to go
against King Edward.

The fourteenth day of May Thomas, the Bastard with a ryotous company of
shipmen, and other of Essex and Kent, came to London, where being denied
passage through the City, he set upon Bishops Gate, Aldegate, London bridge,
etc. along the Thamis side, shooting arrows and Gunnes into the City, fiered
the Suburbs, and brent more than 60. houses, wanne the Bulwarks at Aldegate
and entered the City, but ye Parcolise being let down, such as had entered
were slain, and then the Citizens pursued the rest, as far as Stratforde and
Black Wall, slaying many, and took many prisoners. Thomas the Bastard went
from London Weastwarde, as far as Kingstone upon Thamis, to prosecute King
Edward, but the Lord Scales, with Nicholas Faunte Mayor of Canterbury, by
fair words caused Fawconbridge to return to Black Heath in Kent, from
whence in the night he stale from the host with six hundred horssemenne to
Rochester, and so to Sandwiche, where he abode the Kings coming.

The one and twentieth of May King Edward came to King Henry murdered.
London with thirty thousand men, and the same night king Henry was murdered
in the Tower of London: on the morrow he was brought to Saint Paul's Church in
London, in an open Cophen bare faced, where he bled: thence he was carried to
the Black Friars and there bled: and thence to Chersey Abbay in a boat, where
he was then buried, but since removed to Windsor, where he rests.

Thus ended the King his transitory life, having inioyed as great prosperity,
as favorable fortune could aforde, and as great troubles on the other side,
as she frownyng could pour out, yet in both states he was patiente, and
virtuous, that he may be a pattern of most perfect virtue, as he was a
worthy example of Fortunes inconstancy, he was plain, upright, far from
fraud, wholye given to prayer, reading of Scriptures, and almes-deedes, of
such integrity of life, that the Bishop which had been his Confessor
ten years, auowched that he had not all that time committed any mortal
crime: So continente as suspicion of unchaste life never touched him: and
having in Christmasse a show of young womenne with their bare breasts laid
out, presented before him he immediately departed, with these words, fie, fie,
for shame, forsooth you be to blame: before his marryage he liked not that
women should enter into his Court, and for this respect, he committed his two
brethren by the mothers side, Jasper and Edmonde, to most honest and virtuous
Prelates, to be brought up, so far he was from covetousness, that when
the executors of his uncle the Bishop of Winchester, surnamed the rich
Cardinal, would have given to him 2000. pound, he playnelye refused it,
willing them to discharge the will of the departed, and would scarcely
condescend at length to accept the same some of money toward the endowing of
his Colleges in Cambridge and Eaton: he was religiously affected (as the time
then was) that at principal holidays, he would were sackeclothe next his
skin. Oath he used none, but in most earnest matters these words: forsoothe
and forsooth: he was so pityfull, that when he saw the quarter of a Traitor
against his Crown over Criple Gate, he willed it to be taken away, with
these words: I will not have any Christian so cruellye handeled for my sake:
many great offenses he willinglye pardoned, and receiving at a time a great
blow by a wicked manne which compassed his death, he only said, forsooth,
forsooth, ye do fowelye to smite a King anointed so: another also thruste
him in the side with a sword when he was restoared to his state and Kingdom:
not long before his death, being demanded why he had so long held the
Crown of England unjustly, he replied, my Father was King of England,
quietlye enjoying the Crown all his reign, and further my grandsire was King
of England, and I even a child in my Cradle, was proclaimed and crowned King
without any interruption, and so held fortye years, well near all the
states doing homage unto me, as to my antecessors: Wherefore I may say with
King David: The lotte is fallen unto me in a fair ground, yea, I have a
goodlye heritage, my help is from the Lord which saves the vprighte in
heart.

This good King, of himself always naturally inclined The Kings College in
Cambridge.
to do good, and fearing lest he might seem unthankful to almyghtye GOD for
his great benefittes bestowed upon him since the time he first took upon
him the regimente of the Realm, determined about the six and twentieth year
of his raygne, for his primer notable work (as by the words of his will I
find expressed) to erecte and found two famous Colleges in the honor and
worship of his holy name, and for the increase of virtue, the dilation of
cunning, and establishment of Christian Faith, whereof the one in Cambridge,
to be called his College royal of our Lady and Saint Nicholas: And the
other at Eaton beside Windsor, to be called his College of our blessed
Lady. And for the performaunce of this his devout purpose, he enfeffed
certain Bishops with other Noble and worshipful personages by his letters
patents with lands and possessions, parcel of his enheritance of the Duchy of
La^caster, to the clear value of well near xxxiiij. hundred pound by year,
which letters patents he after confirmed by his Act of Parliament, declaring
also by his will unto his said feoffees, his intent and meaning, how the same
should be employed upon the edifications of his said two Colleges, whereof in
my judgment the device is so excellent, and the buildings so princely and apt
for that purpose, as I can not omit to set forth unto you the very plat of
the whole College in Cambridge, even as I find mentioned, almost Verbatim, in
his said will, supposing that if the rest of the house had proceeded according
to the Chapel already finished (as his full intent and meaning was) the like
College could skant have bin found again in any Christian land. The words of
the Will are thus. As touching The Chapel.
the dimensions of the Church of my said College, of our Lady and Saint
Nicholas of Cambridge, I have devised and appointed, that the same Church shall
contain in length 288. foot of assise, without any Isles, and all of the
wideness of xl. foot. And the length of the same Church from ye West end unto

stall, unto the greece called Gradus Chori. 90 foot, for 36. stals on either
side of the same Quyre, aunscoering to lxx. fellows and ten Priests conduits,
which must be de prima forma. And from the said stalles unto ye East end of
the said Church, lxij. foot of assise. Also a Reredosse bearing the
Roodelofte, departing the Quire and the body of the Church, containing in
length xl. foot, and in breadth xiiij. foot. The walls of the same Church to
be in height 90. foot imbattelled, vawted and Charerooffed, sufficiently
butteraced, and every Butterace fined with finials. And in the East end of the
same Church shall be a Window of nine days, and betwixt every Buttrace a
Window of five days. And betwixt every of the same Buttraces in the Body of
the Church, on both sides of the same Church a Closet with an Alter therein,
containing in length twenty foot, and in breadth ten foot, vawted and finished
under the soil of the I Will windows. And the pauement of ye Church to be
enhansed 4. foot above ye ground without. And ye height of the pauement of the
Quire one foot and a half above the pauement of the Church. And the
